Repaired an inflatable air mattress with this patch kit.  Good instructions and very easy to use.  It was a little difficult getting the air mattress to lay flat and smooth enough where the hole was in order to get a large enough area to apply the patch.  This was no fault of the repair kit - just the fact that the mattress is a heavy gauge vinyl and difficult to manipulate when deflated.  I used rubbing alcohol to clean the area to be patched to assure a good bond.  Patience and a lot of tugging and rubbing to get a flat area paid off.  The patch held with two adults sleeping on the queen mattress.
I was a bit skeptical when I saw the package, but it did the job.  The instructions could be better.  I would have expected there to be a requirement for scuffing the surface (I did a light scrub with a piece of sandpaper) and for them to specify which side of the patch to apply the adhesive on (they are of slightly different textures).  They could have been more clear on the six and kind of weight to use.  Also, there are four patches of exactly the same size and enough adhesive to do 20 that size.  I would have traded some adhesive for a variety of patches.However, all in all, it was a great value, simple to use, and seemingly durable.  I would recommend it.
We had a rip in our aerobed on the bottom-middle.  I used this to repair it and it's held up really well!  We even had my lineman brother sleep on it for a week (without deflating it once) and it was just fine!  (For non-football fans, that means he weighs somewhere between 275-375 lbs.)  Both of my parents slept on it for a weekend, also, and it stayed inflated throughout the entire time.  Bonus: it's super easy to apply.
Beaching a PWC is just not a good idea.  You see a lot of people do it, but what you don't see is their hulls destroyed gel coat, or their PWC in the shop in a few weeks because they have debris in their intake.This anchor keeps your PWC just off the shore, safely floating in a few feet of water.  It is easy to fill with sand or rocks, and when it is time to go it cleans up and stores just as easy.  When you're ready to go out for a ride, there is a buoy on the hook so you'll know where to clip back on when you head back in.I wouldn't hit the water without mine.
LOVE IT LOVE  LOVE IT. read concerns about the structural build of the stitching on the bag to rope interface. Ignore them, the bag is well built for it's intended use. Just fill it with sand, rocks, or weights and make sure you pick it up from the bottom of the bag, not the rope! And you should be O.K. But if you toss it from the rope just remember you are inducing more force onto the stitching interface due to the mass x acceleration of the swinging action. Play it safe and take care of your anchor:) enjoy
I used this for a while. Though hollow plastic I felt it was designed to hold a camper from rolling and it did. One day I forgot to remove it when pulling out and it seems to take very little pressure moving forward to flatten it like a pan cake so I though my 50,000 investment may be better served with a heavy duty galvanized wheel chock that wont give in and even let me move over it by mistake and let me know its holding solid if I ever did again roll forward over it.
I don't deny this is a well-made product at an affordable price, and it may likely work for your purposes, but the angle of the chock is designed for a really big tire given the size of the chock.  They look downright silly on my Coleman pop-up with 13" tires.  Only about the first rung and a half of the chock actually touches the tire, so the rest is left sticking out in nowhere.  I'm left thinking a simple block cut from a 2x4 will work just as well for me. Maybe an improvement to the existing design would be to make the back half gently curved down as well, rather than a straight shot. Then users would have two options, one which could fit smaller tires better.  As is, they really are over-kill on small popup campers.  Sticking with a simple block of wood works too.  I'll be returning my chocks.
The point is to stop your car right where you want it in the garage.  This does that just fine.  I have rolled up on it with a Ford Fiesta and did not damage it.  Your Hummer might be more of a challenge.  The only down side is its width.  I have no problem hitting the thing, but we have yet to see if my lady and do the same.  If that is an issue you might put two of them side by side for her.  BTW, I used silicone sealant to make sure the thing can't scoot when contacted.  That worked perfectly.
I typically use pavers I have in the yard to chock both sides of one tire when I do any work on my truck, but they aren't much higher than 1-1.5".  These are nicer to keep in my garage than to bring in a muddy paver.  Since it's yellow, it's easy to spot in my garage, and they don't slip.  I've tested them by giving my truck a little gas while these are on and they prevent me from rolling.  They look good and do their job.  I like em....
I bought 2 of these, one to keep in my truck for road side emergencies and the other for automotive work use at home. The few times I have used them they work well, but just so you know they have a recommended expiration date on them. I think this is due to their intended use as a RV chock, where they would sit in the sun a lot and would degrade. But again they are cheap, and if the worries you, just buy a new one and toss out the suspect one!
The vessel I'm currently assigned to has 2 pairs of these in their navigation tool chest, and they seem pretty ubiquitous elsewhere as well as I've encountered them on multiple vessels before.  All in all, they are a good solid divider, well made, and have the advantage of holding their position for precise plots.  Personally though, I find them uncomfortable to hold and the extra tension caused by the wheel mechanism requires more force to adjust which over time becomes a nuisance.  For open ocean, 1 plot/hr, these are fine; to sit down for an hour or two and use them to plow through a pile of chart corrections, not so much.  I much prefer the W&P Millenniums, but these will do the job just fine if you're truly concerned about the dividers moving while positioning them.
Bought this 6 months ago, I have been using it and happy with it. 12g rounds stay in there nice and tight. My only recommendation would be to purchase the 6 shot. I was concerned about the forearm having trouble and didn't want to have to swap that out too at first considering I was new to the weapon. Well, 6 months later I am upgrading to the Magpul forearm and just bought the 6 shot to go along with it. You'll want the more rounds if you're not wearing a chest rig or shell sling. Gave it a 4 because it does block the serial number on the Remington 870 when other ones do not, but for the price it is worth it.
Easy install, easy use. This unit is solid, and even the plastic clips feel very sturdy and I have faith it will last a long time.My only qualm with this is that it is the alternative to the 6-shot, which sometimes is a little long. It would be nice to have a 5-shot option, or even the option of interchangeable cover plates (the part with the shell clips that is attached to the metal base plate) with the different options. The 4- and 6- shot are close to the same price, and once I receive my new, shorter, fore end, I would be able to use the 6-shot, but don't want to spend the same money again to have the extra 2 shells.
I was concerned with a few things with this item:  ease of installation, durability, external profile, and how it fit the shells.  Bottom line, it was great with everything.  Simply punch out the trigger assembly pins and the screws go right in and screw into the base plate, making it fit really solid on the side of the receiver.  Seriously, it doesn't budge.  The fact that it holds 4 shots and not 6 is a good thing.  6 would be wayyyy too many in my opinion.  If you need that many, get one of those stock sleeves or a bandolier sling.  4 shells is really the perfect amount.  On that note, the shell holders are the perfect median of flexibility and rigidity.  The shells slide in and out easily, but don't require an abusive amount of force.  Seems like it should last a long time, I'm really pleased.
I have both a model 870 tactical and 870 express fits on both fine the long action of the express means this is a good alternative to stock mounted nylon shell holders the tactical action is shorter and can handle the 6 shell holder.  as for shells fitting they hole top or bottom mounted in the holder however the less shells you have in it the less grip on the remaining shells the holder seems to have also the smaller screw that comes with this to replace the forward pin was very snug fitting and took some GENTLE Tapping to get in just be careful not to strip the threads all in all good product will buy the 6 shell one to mount on my tactical 870 this will be going on my bird gun
It shoots like a field point out to 30 yards. Beyond that it is unpredictable. I have used them for target practice in the woods. I have shot them at rocks and tree stumps. They bounce off without damaging the arrow. I shot them at a large ground squirrel at 15 yards, thinking it would only crush it without causing excessive damage. I was wrong. It punched completely through both shoulders leaving a 1.5 inch entry wound and a 2.5 inch exit. I had planed to use these on grouse, but now I am not sure they won't destroy them. I also tried a cheaper brand of slip on rubber broad heads. The slip on stopped on impact, and the arrow punched through the rubber. So this broadhead is better then those slip on, but I'm not sure rubber is the way to go.

Well, it's a toilet seat. Just like it says, it snaps onto a 5gal bucket and that's about it. I took a tip from other reviewers and just used heavy duty trash bags instead of the expensive ones sold to go with this. I took it camping and lined the bottom of the trash bag with kitty litter, and kept another bucket next to it with kitty litter and a scoop inside to sprinkle on top after each use.The bucket seems pretty stable with this seat attached to it,but I made a base out of wood for the bucket to sit in and it works great. Set the whole unit up inside a shower tent,and with the seat cover and kitty litter there was no noticeable smell.The seat itself is actually more &#34;roomy&#34; than the porta potty I used on a previous camping trip. The plasic is a little flimsy but heck for the price I think it's a pretty good deal.
Very comfy seat, I am 6' and 215lbs.  I fish out in the ocean, sometimes 50 miles from shore, and when ya gotta go, well, you know the story.  Before we were using a 5 gallon bucket with no seat and it can be uncomfortable and leave a ring around  your behind.  This seat fit my generic 5 gallon  bucket very snugly, AND, is comfortable to sit on. My crew and I are now, &#34;HAPPY CAMPERS,  I mean, &#34;HAPPY FISHERPEOPLE&#34;.
Used it for the first time while camping this weekend.  We needed something for our camper that did not take up lots of space and this was the perfect answer.  I purchased a standard 5 gal bucket from our local store and the seat snapped tightly to it!  We used 8 gal kitchen bags and double bagged the bucket and added a bit of kitty litter (adding a little each time we went).  No more walking to the outhouse in the middle of the night for this mom, or any more accidents with the kids because they can't make it in time.  One happy camper!
Simply attach this seat cover to a 5 gallon(or smaller) plastic bucket and you have a perfectly fine toilet to sit on.  I recommend lining the bucket with a trash bag and adding some kind of absorbent i.e cat litter, wood shavings, especially if its expected to be used multiple times.  This is really great for boat owners who have an on-board head, but do not want to put up with the hassle of cleaning it.  I have to go on a boat so rarely, I do not feel too bad about washing my solid waste into the ocean so I just leave the bag out.  Also girls do not have the advantage of being able to pee off the side of the boat like men do, so having one of these for them is much appreciated.

I took this pole salmon fishing. It performed well. Cast very well. I have a glass blank by South Bend that I finally wore out the eyes.I have a Berkley glass trout rod in the same condition. Depending on how much it will be to strip, equip, tie and finish these poles is what determines if I will keep them. This Okuma advertises it is made of glass fiber. We will see. To me glass rods have greater casting distance, and unlike as advertised, all other constructions of blanks are not as sensitive to light bumps as the glass. Many of my acquaintances want to go back to glass only. They are looking at garage sales to find glass poles to rebuild. If this Okuma is truly glass construction maybe I will be wondering if I should rebuilt it in 25 years.Aug. 12 2011, I have fished this rod several times now on the Nestuca River in Oregon, and this is a great rod. I am VERY happy.
I love this rod! Like others have said, I had to sand down the butt end connections, the tip end connection was OK. When I received the package, the box was mashed and mangled and made me worry that the rod was broke, but upon opening and checking the rod from end to end, was OK. There could be some peanuts or scrap paper packed in around the rod to protect it in shipment. For those that don't know what peanuts I'm referring to is Styrofoam  pieces. Very good price and product seems to be made to last of good quality and would recommend to anyone that  is in the market for this type of rod.

Barely flex the tip and you can hear it crack and pop.  Im afraid a decent size fish will destroy it. BTW, I ordered the 7' for channel cats. Ill keep it as a backup or loaner. But, if you buy it, you will get a rod that is worth exactly what you pay for it. Im going back to Ugly Stick Catfish rods.

I use the on the open flame of my bbq grill.  I cook with propane gas on high heat.  My favorite dish cooked on this pan is country fried steak aka cubed steak.  When I am in a hurry (that is always) I turn the gas on full throttle pour an ounce or two of cooking oil on the griddle.  Within a few minutes my griddle is at 450 to 500 degrees F.  Sometimes it flames up but that is fine.  The coating does not come off and shows no sign of damage.  I have repeated this process many times with great success.  If everyone wants to come over for a sample I will unwrap the other griddle.  I can cook at least four steaks at a time on one griddle.  If I put both griddles on the fire I could cook enough for a party.

I did not peel and was super easy to clean. i will continue to use this at home and while out camping. the size is good. i can make about 6 small pancakes as shown in the product picture. This product is excellent for anyone just getting into the game of tennis. For the price range, this hopper is a great option compared to what you'll find in most sporting good stores. I've seen some reviews say it isn't very durable, but I've been using mine for several months now without issue. It sits in the trunk of my car and I only bring it out when I'm using it.I imagine it's not built to withstand hours and hours of teaching lessons with everyday, but for the casual player it's more than fine.
This is basically the same ball hopper I had 20 years ago with a few minor set backs.  The first issue was that 20 years ago, the basket was one piece, now the four sides are screwed together, so you constantly have to worry about the nuts getting loose and loosing them.  The other issue is that it takes a lot of muscle to get the legs into the notches to get it to stand up.  I can do it, but I'm pretty sure my wife would not be able to.  With the legs int he notches, it's pretty stable.  Once you do get the legs in the notches, it takes some more muscle to get them out.  Overall, I think it was a good choice.
Great little unit, and LITTLE indeed!  Packs away so you hardly notice it, great to keep behind the truck seat for those unexpected 'stops'.  Not much room for gear, but again it's a back up type unit.  Haven't caught anything significant with it yet, just some small trout, panfish, etc. but good for a fun afternoon - or a spare combo for when you have a guest.  Treat it like the ultralight unit it is, the case makes it's a little bulky for small pole but protects it very well, keeps it organized.  Don't expect it to replace full sized gear, and it's a five star.  If its your only rig?  Eh, 3-4 star depending on what you fish.
had mine for about 5 years use it all the time at least once a month . if your only fishing in small lakes or ponds this is perfect you will not have miles of line with this pole it wasnt meant for that ive still managed to catch plenty of fish with mine and just recently broke a section (user error it was crushed by spare tire in the bed of my truck ) . it will catch respectable fish ive caught kokanee salmon walleye tons of rainbow and a few bass on this pole the case was the first thing to break no biggy it fits in my messanger bags spare compartment perfectly anyway . good product thinking of geting another one just to have around for freinds on hikeing trips etc
I read most of the reviews prior to buying this combo. Yes it is small but has a great feel to it. As far as being a pain to replace in the hard case I'd suggest some patience. Worked for me.My complaint is the anti-reverse isn't working. I gave it a 3 star because Amazon jumped right on the defect and hopefully the next reel works like it should. The reel is actually a "sweepfire 10002B"made in Viet Nam. I can't wait to hook a shell fish on this light action rod. If the next one doesn't work I'll trash it. Have a good un.07 Aug update. Received my replacement kit and this time the reel works just fine. The only problem was one of the dividers in the case was broken. The package did not appear damaged so I figure it happened at the factory. Case still works fine so no biggy.
Great rod to use if you're just looking to fish off the dock or on land.  I wouldn't use it deep-sea fishing though.  The combo is meant for a maximum of 4 pound testline.  I have used it the whole summer and haven't had any issues with it.  I've put alot of force on the rod trying to break loose of many snags and the rod hasn't broken yet.  The Reel has 3 setting:1st setting - Left - allows the reel to spin in either direction (reel-in or let out more line)2nd setting - Center - allows the reel to make a clicking sound when something is pulling your line3rd setting - Right - one way reeling that locks doesn't let the fish get away unless it breaks your line.
I've received my rod on time. well few days after I got it, I went to fish for some panfish, and what I can say about the reel is that works very good even for casting I've tried some spoons and it worth, and about the rod, it is very flexible I caught 2 largemouth bass of about 6 pounds ea. it bended like if will break down, but finally nothing bad happened,I totaly recomend this kit,it came with out line but is good after all.
I've managed to stuff a Rapala Minnow Rap, a small popper, a Mepps Aglia Streamer, and a small square bill crank in the largest compartment, soft plastics (crappie tubes, small grubs etc), hooks, split shot and swivels in one of the small compartments, and a mess of panfish flies in the other.  For an angler that is either kayak fishing, or shore fishing and needs to walk a lot, space is premium.  This well made case will work well.  I had a nearly identical product called Hot Lids which was the same size and shape, only the shade of blue was different.  You &#34;could&#34; clip this to a caribiner, but with the risk of it possibly opening up and spilling the contents, I'd recommend keeping it in a jacket, jeans, or vest pocket.  I nearly exclusively bank fish, so having a few go-to baits in my pocket is perfect for a quick excursion.
The fit is good (feels good on my flat, hairless face) and it functions well.  The straps aren't the best and can slip a bit with use, but you can make your own or use a set you like from another/other mask.  In the deep south heat it can get pretty wet inside the mask, but it won't effect the mask to much (and it is the same for all masks).  Can't beat it for the price.  Cheaper than the big box AO paint masks, or 3M masks, but you can't find replacement filters as easily either.
Who is that masked man? That's what my granddaughter wanted to know after seeing me wearing the AO Safety Woodworker's Respirator. It has worked fine for me thus far. I experienced no fogging and no face or head discomfort. I agree with another reviewer who stated he didn't have the desire to take it off and burn it like some other masks. Well put! After using a few at home as well as in the USMC, I know exactly what he means. This one is lightweight and as comfortable as you're going to get wearing this type. I haven't had mine on for longer than 30 minutes in mild temperatures. I can't say it would never get annoying if worn for an extended period of time in hot weather because, frankly in my experience, they all do. Don't forget to order yourself extraAO Safety Replacement Filters. ~ The Boss
the mask is fairly small, appears to be cheaply made especially the rubber strap - this strap will not stand the test of time. had i actually seen it in the hardware store i never would have bought, particularly at the near to $15 price. To me, the price/value would be more apt in the $8 range. It certainly does not look like the pic on amazon - the pic makes it appear larger than it is, the surface area of the filter hence will be limited in it's ability to handle larger volumnes of air over time- but then they want you to buy replacement filters faster.
I purchased these for my kids and for handing out to my son's scout troop.  The intention is that these be used as safety devices so that if they are lost or in trouble they can blow the whistles instead of yelling.The whistles are black with a ring that can be hung on a backpack, or which can be strung on a cord.  They are loud enough to hear from a pretty good distance, without breaking eardrums.Definitely recommend.  The price I bought them at made the whistles about 70 cents each.
These little whistles make a lot of noise and are great for hiking bags, cars and bug-out bags. If you had to get noticed you cannot yell very loud and these whistles make a lot of racket to get noticed- with very little energy expended.  At the very affordable prices stick em in your car and everywhere else you can think of -1 dozen great price and they work very well. I bought an assortment of various types and these work very well I consider these the best that I could get. Some of the pricey ones do not work very well and are marginal and big bucks. GET THESE- THEY ARE GREAT and inexpensive and they all work great from a little puff to a loud blow a lot of ear piercing whistle tone. Stick them - with a lanyard-to the pepper spray and you have another self-defense tool to attract attention if the situation gets unsafe.
This 32 inch yellow Wiffle Bat is the classic hard plastic Wiffle Bat going back many decades.  I started using this Wiffle Bat back in 1976 while playing backyard Wiffleball and I still use it to this day because it's irreplaceable.  In other words, a classic.  It is very durable.  I've only owned maybe three or four of them in my lifetime because they are durable.  In addition to using the regular standard size Wiffle balls, I also like to fool around with the plastic practice golf ball "Wiffle" balls.  It's more challenging to hit the smaller Wiffle balls.  All in all, a great product that will last.
When my six year old entered T-Ball for the first time, I went out to get him one of my childhood favorites, the Wiffle ball and bat. Imagine my surprise when I saw on the package that this all-American toy is still made in the USA! I figured it to be good practice for his swinging and hitting. It brought back many great memories of my grandfather and I playing ball out in the yard. I hope my son has as much fun with his as I did with mine.
This container of 3 Penn Championship tennis balls is exactly the one my parents bought for me one Christmas several years ago, and you know, the reason they bought them was very simple- tennis balls are soft, they bounce, and you can even throw them pretty far.  During my ball fascination, this is *exactly* what I wanted (and my parents liked the fact that a tennis ball sometimes hitting the side of a house or especially a window by mistake would likely NOT cause any damage!)  Truthfully, I've only ever played actual tennis with these balls on a couple occasions, but they worked pretty darn well.  I recommend them.  In fact, these are the only type of tennis balls outside the internet I've ever seen.  Maybe there's other brands but they aren't nearly as well-known.
$2.47 with Free Prime shipping when placed as an add on item.  That makes them about the same, or even a little less than I can find them at Dick's, Sports Authority, and other stores.  And I don't have to go shopping at the terror that is the mall to get to Dick's.I like the Penn Extra Duty.  They are ideal for hard courts and keep their bounce a nice long while.  Great for practice or training.  The only balls I like as much, maybe slightly better are the Wilson US Open Extra Duty.  But they aren't found cheaply on Amazon like these.  So Penn gets the nod.
I don't play tennis.  I can't comment on how these would be on the court.  I bought them to be used in a hand held ball-chucker that I also bought on Amazon.  They fit in the chucker just as nicely as the one that originally came with it (different color, though).  I CAN for sure say that my dog loves to retrieve them!  I asked him if he had any comment but he just looked at me so I guess that means he agrees.  Enjoy!
I bought three.Don't be fooled into buying a cheaper product that includes plastic coated chains and hooks- they are crap and will last 6 months.  This swing is of a build quality you'll find at the finest outdoor park.  Swing seat is THICK 6" black rubber attached to heady duty welded triangles riveted solidly to the swing seat.  After 8 months outdoors with heavy use (several birthday parties, multiple kids/adults at a time etc), these show no noticeable sign of wear or quitting.Buy these, and you can expect your grand-kids to be swinging from them one day.
There is a ton of this stuff, and it lasts a long time. I'm still on my first half block, using it three times a week for several lifts. I have pretty sweaty hands, but rubbing this in allows me to grip it and rip it on my lifts. Make sure you have a spare container to keep this in. I'm using a bagel-sized plastic storage container, which is great for allowing you to scoop out a pinch without making a huge mess. That said, this stuff will leave a powdery mess.
My deadlift had gotten to the point that &#34;grip it and rip it&#34; was no longer cutting it, thanks to my grip slipping/rolling out.This chalk was a VERY good way to help with that problem. One block broken up makes a surprising amount of chalk and should last a long time.The only con I've noticed with it is that it dries out your hands like you wouldn't believe. (Which IS kind of the point.) Have some lotion or something handy for after workouts and you'll be fine, though.
This is a solid bar at a good price. It has the revolving attachment that is nice. It is about what I expected and the price was fair. The only thing I am slightly disappointed with is the angle where it attaches to the cable. It is kind of hard to describe, but when I use it on my low cable doing rows the bars are not perpendicular to the cable. I think this is because the swivel part is not centered between the handles. I'm not sure if other bars are like this or centered more. It's not a deal breaker but if I was making one I'd look into this. I'd give it 3.5 stars. Hope this helps.
I was surprised at how heavy this was, yaaay. I was not sure of the quality to expect but, i am pleased. It should last for ...well, for ever. Its size is just perfect to draw my hands up to my sides on rows - for reference. Connector is smooth, comes with a little bit of grease already in it/on it. Finish is pretty decent.UPDATE; reduced rating, tried using this for triceps and its unusable for any amount of weight due to the curve not being a good stop for your hands and the almost 90degree downward bend. your hands end up buckling upward, half on the straight portion and half on the 90 degree bend of the bar. Sucks for this use, and is now overpriced for being a single use(for rows only) item.
Great tool for an overall upperbody workout.  Take it slow at first, cause you will feel it the next day.  I cycle, run, and lift weights almost daily.  But I was only able to do 5 wheels the first day I got it, and it felt like my abs were going to rip apart. :)  But after just a couple of weeks, I am up to 30 at a time.  Love it.  I can feel it working shoulders, abs, upper and lower back, biceps, triceps, and lats.  Great complement to any workout routine.  A good way to "top-off" after lifting weights.
I've had this for a few days so far. Fairly easy to install, seems about as durable as the original Casio strap (i.e. it should last for a few years and then break, just as all my Casio straps have). It's a good match for the Casio watch. Good thing it came with spring bars, since this watch has solid non-spring bars. One oddity - the strap is slightly wider than the inside of the buckle, so it's a bit hard to pull through.
I agree that the material is flimsy and very lightweight. Think about silicone cellphone cases as comparison. This can be a bad or good trait depending on your use. For me, I broke my other band long ago and wanted to use my Casio sports watch again for outdoor water activities. Having something lightweight on my wrist was ideal. When strapped on, the band feels very comfortable. I can't vouch for durability yet, but I don't think it will stay flexible for too long. But at this price, it's a good buy in my opinion, and besides it includes the spring bars to attach to the watch unlike some other bands. To see if 19mm is right for you, measure with a ruler the inside part between where the springs bars would go. In inches, 19mm is .748, or very close to 3/4 inch. Hope this helps, goodluck!
This "speed loader" does not seem to be very speedy if you have to wiggle it to get the rounds in the cylinder.  When I tried just putting it in straight, it didn't work.  If I wasn't doing it right and have to wiggle it to get it in, then it's really not much of a "speed loader".  It's suppose to be fast, but it doesn't seem that fast to me.  Maybe I just need some practice with it, but it's not what I thought it would be.  Maybe it's better than just using your hands to put the rounds in one by one, especially in an emergency, but it's still too slow if you needed the rounds in in a split life-saving second.  Plus, an accidental inadvertent twist of the knob and you lose all your rounds.  Maybe I'll stick with my failure-proof semi-automatic pistol with spare 10-round magazines in a real emergency.
These work just fine with my S&W revolver.  I have the M&P 340 with some aftermarket VZ grips which are a little thicker than the stock boot grip that comes on the 340.  The speed loaders fits just fine between the VZ grips and the cylinder face, and I haven't experienced any binding of the rounds as I load them.  I also carry .357 Mag rounds instead of .38 Spl.  Even with the extra length of the 357 casings I still have no binding problems.  These loaders hold the rounds in there tight and the the rounds themselves don't giggle around once they are locked into the loader.  These are really reliable loaders... IMHO.
I purchased 3 different pairs of speed loaders for 3 different revolvers.  This one and the 6 round speed loaders work perfectly, but the 7 round one is difficult to lock the rounds in place.That being said, this is a beautiful speed loader.  The rounds lock in with a light twist and fall out just as easily.  This one is also the easiest to load fast in practice, most likely due to only having to get 5 rounds in the cylinder holes instead of 6 or 7 but it's still very easy to use fast.As easy as it locks the rounds in place it unfortunately opens just as easily.  Tried carrying it a bunch of different ways, and so far I had one release the bullets when being carried inside a vest pocket.  That's a major bummer, but carrying in a side speed loader pouch or even inside my pants pocket seems to work just fine.
The speedloader works great. It locks the ammo securely and is easy to use. I purchased 2 for reloads for my carry gun a Ruger SP101 357 magnum. With practice you can reload very quickly with these. Word of advice/warning with the compact revolvers the cartridges only go about half way in before you hit the grip. This is not an issue in my opinion it's due to the compact nature of the revolver. Just drop the loaded speedloader in and twist the knob and let gravity do the rest. A must have for a revolver owner in my opinion.

I wish it would stay this way through their entire lives. But they do loosen up after a few times. They still work good though. Also, I wish they held the rounds better in a snug pocket. I recently bought a Ruger LCR 357 and replaced the Hoag grips with Crimson Trace grips.I have seen several reviews where people have had trouble using the 36-A with the LCR. While the loader is a little tight, I've been using them to compete without an issue; it just takes a bit of practice. I purchased two HKS 36-A Revolver Speedloaders for my newly purchased Ruger LCR .38 Special +p revolver.  The pistol holds only five rounds of .38s since it is rather small and the rounds are rather large, a compromise in both directions.  Still I wanted the additional confidence of have extra rounds at my disposal (this comes from years of owning a Glock 23 .40 cal that my magazines held a maximum of 13 rounds each and 5 just made me uncomfortable).  With the additional purchase of the HKS 203M-P Plain Double Speedloader Case, Black, Medium, I am now back up to being able to have 15 rounds, only with the additional time needed to empty the cylinder of the five casings at a time and quick load five fresh rounds.  Good product at a very good price.
I bought this for my 38.SP and it holds the rounds nice, i did a speed test on my self and noticed that without a speed loader and under stress from a possible gun fight or worse it would take me some 10 seconds or more to fully load 5 rounds, and some got dropped. Also i must say i am not a professional gun shooter so im sure there are a lot of people that can do it better then i can, but i am just speaking as an Avg gun user. Now with this speed loader my best time under stress was about 3-5 seconds or better, which is or could be life or death. So yes i do suggest this item to everyone that needs it!
I own a S&W 642 J frame. This speed loader fails to do its job.  While the literature states that it fits my weapon, this is entirely false.  I have the factory stock grips on the weapon, and the speed loader gets jammed against the grips.  It is anything but a speedy load.  In fact, it will get you dead.  I have unfortunately found that the fiddling with this speed loader to extract it after loading takes substantially longer than simply loading in five shells into the cylinder by hand.  I am trying out some Bianchi Speed Strips (also sold here on Amazon) and will rate those soon. But in the meantime, do not expect this speed loader to work with the 642 or any other J frame.  It will not, and if you take your safety and that of your family seriously, please do not purchase this product.

I like shooting my revolver because I don't have to chase the brass, like I do with my semi-automatic pistols. The downside is the awkwardness of the reload process.This device removes that awkwardness. Just open and drop my old brass into a bag or bucket then seat all 5 bullets at once with this device and I'm off again.For the range I can pre-load these and set them on the bench in front of me. Nice speedloader; works great and seems to be manufactured well. HEADS UP TO CONCEAL CARRY REVOLVER OWNERS. I own a Smith & Wesson .38 Special +P Hamerless Airweight and this speedloader did not work well with it. With the right amount of wiggling and twisting it you could get the bullets to all fall out into the cylinder but I would never recommend relying on that in a firefight. The reason for this happening is because the Airweight pistol's cylinder does not open away from the frame far enough and the black plastic from the speedloader rubs against the frame when trying to insert the bullets. Works well on a full sized frame.
This speedloader has great quality, holds the shells firmly, releases them easily, and works as advertised.  Note that it doesn't quite fit perfectly with the Ruger LCR with standard Hogue grips, as the grips get in the way of it lining up perfectly. So you have to load them at an ever-so-slight angle (and can't put any more than the tips of the bullets in the cylinder) rather than loading them all the way in before releasing them.  The LCR is super compact (but with relatively wide grips), however, and I don't think you'd have that problem with most revolvers listed as working with it.

I bought this speed loader for my Ruger LCR .38 Special. I was a bit hesitant after reading some reviews but it works great. It does take a little wiggle to lock the rounds in place but no more than I have seen with other models. Dropping the rounds out is simple and efficient. The casing of the speed loader does touch the housing of the firearm when loading but it does not impede upon the loading process. Also, it does feel a little cheap in its construction but I will see if it holds up to the test of time.I am pleased overall and will be buying a second.
This speedloader is great for all 38 special ammo, snap caps, or the deal deal.  One small turn (about 1/16th of a rotation) locks them, and an equally small rotation the other way releases them with no snag.  When they are locked in, lock-up is secure, and the rounds will not wiggle at all.  When you release the rounds in your revolver, they slide right in effortlessly.  These are great for storing defensive rounds, or practicing with snap caps.  My local pawnshops all want $20+ for these with all this gun ban mess going on, so not only is this a great product, but a pretty good price as well.Do I recommend it?  If you have a 38 or 357, this is a must have accessory.
I have used these speed loaders for years with a Taurus 851 concealed hammer and stock rubber grips.  The rounds go in smoothly, but need a little jiggle to shake them down into the cylinder.  They are what they are for the money.  A little practice with them and you can get reasonably quick.  I have never had a problem with them and I routinely carry two of them loose in a pocket.  If you carry them loose in a pocket, make sure to check the pocket you carry them in for lint and foreign matter, as well as the speed loaders.  If you want competition fast, this one isn't it.  But it is an inexpensive tool for reloading a revolver faster than 1 round at a time.
I read many reviews and watched YouTube videos about quick loaders before buying 4 of this one.  While the 5Star product appeared to be perfect for the Ruger LCR 38 Special I have, I opted for this one based on price.  The comments about this product not fitting perfectly with a Ruger LCR .38 Special are true, but the imperfection is not so bad that it makes reloading a hassle ... after a few trial reloads, you figure out how to operate it so that you get the fastest reload.  This one gets the job done.  I load all 4 and put them in a small clutch purse I have ... the fit is perfect, so I don't have any problems with carrying them.
This is a good speedloader, I've had one for several years now and just bought another to have a pair.  I'm not a match shooter, so don't know how it would compare to higher-end products, but for casual range use or having a speedloader loaded up with snakeshot in my pocket while out in the field, it does its job.  I'm still learning how to use it, I have a little trouble lining up the ammunition with their corresponding hole in the cylinder, so definitely won't be participating in any speed-shooting competitions, but I like having 5 rounds ready to go instead of loading individual rounds each time.

HKS makes a quality speedloader, and has for a while. Their products are well-made and generally work as advertised. In the past I've used LCR and Smith & Wesson Model 637 speedloaders with no issue.I bought this loader for my 1968-manufactured unshrouded second-generation Colt Detective Special with the full-size factory wood grips. The loader won't seat completely due to the grip. I can still drop the rounds at a slight angle and it is workable, but given that this loader is listed as compatible with the Colt, the fact that it doesn't work with factory grips is unacceptable.Four stars for quality, minus one for not working well with a revolver it was advertised to work with.

It is too big to get lined up with the cylinder  because it is agenst the frame of the gun. It will only allow the tips of 4 out of six of the bullets to be placed in the cylinder then you have to relice the bullets and guide them in the rest of the way after you move the speed loader out of the way. I have two of these speedloaders, both for .38 revolvers. One is a 5 shot and the other, a 6 shot. The loaders themselves are fine and certainly of high quality for the price. However, both of them snag on the grips and have to be wrestled into position. It is also a bit awkward to unlock the rounds when they are in the chambers. I have recommended these loaders to my friends but insist that they use them on their own firearms to see if they encounter the same problems that I have.
This speed loader works for 6 shot 45 colt revolvers, such as the Governor. Any negative reviews I have seen for this are due to consumers lack of knowledge. To clear up issues from previous reviews: 1. Of course this six shot cartridge holder will not fit your five shot revolver. 2. The number 25-5 is a model number, nothing more. 3. No, 410 shells and 45 ACP rounds will not work in this speed loader. Only 45 colt. I have several speed loaders for different calibers by this company and have never had any issues.

I met a guy at the range who gave me the info on what he ordered. His were 5 round speed-loaders. They sent me 6 round speed-loaders. I note from another reviewer that this has happened before. Like the earlier reviewer, I now have to return them. There is not a contact the seller link on this products page. Too bad. I might have been able to get the right information  the first time! I got mine for Charter Arms .44 Bulldogs as well. A 4" Target Bulldog and a 2.5" carry gun. The Bulldogs are so compact (and the cartridge they fire so large) that the speed loader just barely fits. As the first reviewer said, you have to jiggle things a bit to get the rounds to drop.It is not as easy as my S&W; Model 29, where there's plenty of clearance and it's dead easy to use the speedloader. As was said, though, it's much faster than dropping the rounds in one at a time. I got two just for the sake of convenience, and I'm glad I did. I got these to make shooting at my practice range easier. They needed a little breaking it but, after reloading each about 3-5 times, they all work smoothly and as expected now. I've used numerous types and brands of ammo including reloads and they all work perfectly now. I'm using these with a '74 S+W .38Spl K-frame square butt revolver. I had to change grips because the ones that came on the gun were in the way of the loader. The new grip also has an integrated laser for quick targeting and, if needed, hopefully making your target think twice about attacking you. I re-stock ATMs part time and this is the setup I carry when I'm moving money around. I always carry it loaded and with at least 2-3 speed loaders loaded and ready - just in case. So far, knock on wood, I haven't had to use it in that situation.
This is a nice little speedloader for the price.  The rounds don't fit 100% secure when locked in place, but this hasn't been a problem for me.I will be buying another.  4/5 stars, and I only took one star off because of the slight "jiggle" of the rounds when it is locked in place.It feels like quality material, and it works quick, releases the rounds when you want it to, and is a good fit on my S&W; model 10 .38 special.
This is the "10A" HKS speedloader.  It is skinny enough that it will load my Dan Wesson 15-2 .357 with the Hogue grip.  Certain other six-shot speedloaders will not fit because there is not enough room between the edge of the speedloader and the side of the revolver for the cylinders to line up with the bullets.  I am imagining that this problem exists with certain smaller revolvers and grips.  This one works well with my Dan Wesson and still does a great job with larger revolvers such as my Ruger GP100.  Recommended.  RJB.
These loaders are a little to big to work with stock grips on a rossi 972, however using a sander, you can bevel the back edge, and they will work.  This is far from a perfect solution, but I've tried safariland comp II, and they won't work on this model at all.  I doubt Comp I would work, but I don't know about comp IIIIf I get free time, I'll upload some pics of the mods.  Go slowly, test fit frequently -- you probably don't want to over-do it.  I also sanded down the rubber grips at the interference point a little (Remove the grips from the gun first, duh).When finished, best operation comes from inserting the ammo just past the crimp line, then releasing.  It's not perfect -- sometimes it kinda binds, but it's faster than loading individually or with speed-strips.Primarily used with 38 spl, The longer 357 rounds increase the difficulty of using these.
Never owned a speedloader before but I decided to purchase a few for my GP100 .357 Magnum revolver. At the tiime, I didn't know of any other make but the HKS seemed to be a quality product. I haven't changed my mind about that after using this product for some time now. Simplicity itself and they work beautifully. i now know there are &#34;other&#34; speedloaders out there but you would be hard pressed to beat the HKS for reliability and, almost impossible to beat the product for the price.
If you are engaged in speed shooting, these are just about perfect. I had my seamstress aunt make a band that fits around my left upper thigh. I thread this on, fill the carriers and stick 'em in. I can flip the cylinder out of my 686 with my right hand and push the empties while I grab a new set and drop them in with my left in about two and a half seconds. I normally set the flaps so that they're only holding on by about an eight of an inch.
These little pouches are great. I've bought 5 so far. I use them for every size speed loader, and also for my little bitty North American Arms .22 revolver extra cylinders. The pouches are a little tight for the aluminum 5-Star speed loaders for my Taurus 608's 8 shot .357 Magnum. [But they fit.] And the pouches were way loose for my NAA spare cylinders. [I just took a piece of round wooden dowel material that fit the pouch, cut it to the correct length, and drilled a hole down the middle the appropriate size for the cylinders and I was in business.] The pouches aren't particularly "dressy" like a leather one would be, but I take them to the range and they are very functional for my purposes.
Fits 5 and 6 shot compact speed loaders, .38 spc, .357 mag and .45 colt. All fit after letting a full speed loader sit in it over night. This is especially true for a 6 shot .45 colt. Only issues I see at this point are first it has to be a compact speed loader (meaning it can only have the small knob on the top as a release mechanism), anything larger won't allow the top flap to close. Second, the velcro on the top flap that serves as the retention device, does not always feel very secure. It may be just me, but I don't want a speed loader falling to the floor any more tthan I want my handgun falling. However, I did give this item 4 stars based on the price and capacity.
I use this in combination with the Safariland J-C7 speed loader.These are cheaply priced.  The downside is material.  There is obviously no stiffness which can make getting at your speed loaders somewhat clumsy.  I was fumbling with this a bit at the range while practicing fast reloads with my .38.  The tricky part is getting your fingers on the speed loader without pushing the sides down onto the loader.  On the plus side, they will accommodate different brands and you could probably even fit a spare black powder cylinder in them if you are a cap and ball enthusiast.All in all they are a good buy.  They are cheaper than the leather versions.  But it would be nice to see the same product with some sort of reinforcement stitched into the sides of the speed loader compartment.
Although the description says "One size case fits all speed loaders" it should say that "one size case fits all HKS speed loaders".  Other than that caveat, the product does just what it promised to do.  If you have a different brand speed loader, then you might not be able to use this case.  Since HKS makes speed loaders for almost every caliber, this should not be an issue.  I have both HKS speed loaders and non-HKS speed loaders so I won't be able to universally use this.
These work for their intended purpose. I carry them on the belt with my S&W 357. Others have said that they don't have the form that the leather does, but once they are loaded and put on the belt, a little cheap hair spray will stiffen them right up. Besides, loading the speed loaders and putting them in the pouches isn't exactly where time is a factor. What counts is when you drop the empty cartridges on the ground and reach for the speed loader that matters. In that fashion, the velcrow works just fine.
If you carry a revolver, this is a good case for your speedloaders that won't take up much space, stick out, or be uncomfortable.  I've used hard cases that are quicker, but those are too bulky, and tend to jab me when I sit down.  This is more comfortable and doesn't look like it's carrying ammo.  The single layer material is strong enough, and makes it more compact than bulkier padded nylon cases.  It is a little floppy though, so it's not going to offer you the fastest access to your reloads, but it makes for a good compromise between big stiff cases, and fumbling around in your pockets.
The set I received actually contains twelve very well made and finished brass jags in an upright standing opaque plastic box roughly 4"W x 1"D x 2"H with a continuous hinged snap-close lid.  The jags range from .17 to .45 caliber.  They are far superior to the plastic jags included with an otherwise fine universal cleaning kit, and fit the sectional cleaning rod supplied with that kit well.  Price seemed to me quite reasonable for the finish, caliber range, weight and convenient, durable packaging of this product.  If, as I expect, it survives three years of use in good condition, then I would raise the rating to five stars.I regret this is not a US source product.
I was using the old pin the cloth through the eye hole set before buying this, and I wish I knew years ago I was doing it wrong. With the old eyehole set it would take about 6 patches to really clean the bore due to the limited *star shaped* surface area of the patch, the older/people who have used this before know what I am talking about. With this Jag set, the entire patch is touching the bore, and it only took 4 patches to come back with a clean cotton. More efficient, and a small money saver, a definite must have.
The set of jags is well marked which was one of my primary gripes with other sets.  My old eyes really appreciate that now-a-days!  The set does come with pretty much a full set of calibers, although I'd imagine that you'll wear out the .30 caliber and .22 calibers the fastest.  The keyholes for mounting are a nice touch too if you want to keep them out in your shop.  When you first get them they are quite difficult to pry out of the holder since the plastic is pretty firm.  Give it some time and they'll be your go to set.
Excellent Tipton quality jag set.Brass so you won't have to worry about your barrel if the jag wears through the patch (or catches a corner)Sizes are just right but you have to make sure the patch isn't too large (I find round patches work just the same as the square, as long as you don't have them too big)I think the thread size must be standard for all but the .17 which is the finer thread size.If you catch this set on sale (under thirteen for me) you're getting a great deal.
I got mine today and after figuring out how to set the rotating stop to fit my particular mag (mine has two mag settings available: .380 and 9mm), the only other simple thing to do was find the most comfortable and natural position to hold the HKS so feeding was smooth and effortless.  I know the HKS only cost about a third the price of the lula but if others believe that cost is the one qualifying factor to gauge an equipment's effectiveness, I say more power to them--have at it.  I don't expect my HKS to last forever but, for price and sheer functionality, I'll stick with it any day.  My next speedloader for the other hand cannon will be an HKS, as well.  =))
Say goodbye to the sucky experience of loading your magazines at the range!I have a Hi Point C9 9mm and this loader makes my range experience so much better.  No more fumbling around putting rounds in a mag, no more sore fingers, no more struggling to get the last couple rounds in.I love this thing and can't say enough good about it.  It is tough and made of quality materials.  The magazine fits perfectly inside it.  I am 100% pleased with this product.If you are on the fence about buying one, I can tell you that you won't regret your purchase.
Some  did not like this because it plastic. Partner loves it for easy of loading mag, (loaded over 50 mags with no problems) Alot easy if you have problems with thumbs I bought two was not sure of the size range, plus have other cal to load. Both were great match. For small thin single stack mags the 943 is better the 459 which still load them but has more play. Has adjustment at bottom to hold mag. Plus you dont need a table to load them  or hold the mag from moving is what my partner loved about it.
I just got this "thing" and tried it out on the Bersa 380 OEM magazine and the Pro-Mag after-market magazine designed for this gun. IT WORKS ... and it works great... no more chopped up thumbs, and I can load all 7 rounds in each mag lickety-split where on the Bersa 380's mag, depending on the ammunition, I could load only six rounds, and with much difficulty.Longevity?? Who cares. For 12 bucks just buy another one down the road in a few years.Oh, and by the way, the instructions are a little vague; but if you cannot figure out how this thing works in less than a minute, you probably should not be owning a semi-automatic weapon to begin with, let alone being allowed to reproduce.
Well I have to say that at first when I was reading about it in AMAZON and checking them out YOUTUBE I was like &#34;yeah right&#34; but I have to say this works great.  I used it several time at home before I take it with me to the range & I have to say it works great!!!!  Makes reloading the magazines easy & fast.  Using them at the range is perfect plus it doesn't hurt my fingers from reloading the mags at the range & it makes target practice more fun.
This thing works well on single stack 380s.  You do need to adjust a couple of places, but once you do it is a champ.  It needs better instructions, but I saw a video on U-tube comparing it to a more expensive model and they showed how to adjust it.  Once it is adjusted it is easy to hold the magazine and add ammo till the magazine is filled.  It does feel like the plastic won't last forever but if it breaks, I can afford another one.  It works easier than the one in the box that came with my double stack pistol .Great product.
I purchased this for a Springfield XDs 9mm.  I have a similar one for another model and love it. This one is adjustable, and would be great if it fit my mag. Does not work with XDs 9mm, it is too narrow. So the statement that it would work with almost all single stacks is not accurate. But the concept and design worked great overall, and deserves a good rating for the mags it does fit.I love this brand and approach for fast range reloading, and have used it in the past. Saves my thumb!I ordered a different model for a replacement. HKS451 and am hopeful because comments indicate it should work with my mag.Would have given 5 stars if it fit mine, but went with 4 due to lack of specifics in the description.
While familiar with speed loaders for larger calibers, this one took a little time to adjust to.  Unlike my other speed loaders, this one does not fully seat the rounds in the cylinder of my two year old Taurus 94.  Using R******** 22 long rifle brass-plated hollow point rounds, the speed loader easily allowed the bullet to enter the cylinders but not the casing.  The knurled aluminum knob is secured on the underside in such a way as to prevent the speed loader from sitting flush on the cylinder. I spoke with HKS about this and was assured that the one I was using was not an outlier.Once that is recognized, you can adjust your technique.  When used with the Speedbeez 4 banger 9 shot Speed Block (sold by Amazon), it makes reloading fast and reliable - no more dropped rounds.There are other speed loaders available that may operate without this issue but they are far pricier and hopefully I can adapt to the restriction.
I have this on my range.  It works great.  Shoot it with 9mm from AR-15 or handgun.  38 special, you name it.  The only issue I had is I can't get it in the ground (it's hard ground).  My solution was to get plastic tupperware tray a few inches deep and fill it with quickcrete.  Then, set this in there.  Now I can move it and it never gets knocked over.  I own a ton of steel targest and I highly recommend this one....
I'm shooting this target with a 9mm and it has zero trouble withstanding those rounds.  I'm ordering a second so that I can go back and forth between them as it takes a few seconds for the plates to stop spinning.  I just spray them with orange paint once the color has been sufficiently blasted off.  My target range is on my personal property and is a narrow lane cut into dense thicket, so I have angled slightly to ensure any bullet splatter will ricochet to the side (which also goes into a hill) instead of back at me.  I don't have any worries about standing at 15-20 yards or using FMJ.  Wear your shooting glasses and have fun.
I bought this cleaning rod to use on my .22LR caliber rifles. It does work okay on them but I think it is really designed to work best with 22 caliber centerfire rifles like .223 or 22-250, etc. It is a tight fit when using it with a .22LR caliber rifle. But it does work and I still use it on my .22LR rifles. I thought the coating on the rod would be great to help protect the bore of the rifles but it seems to chip and scrape off easily on contact with sharp edges so I am not sure the coating is really needed. Other than that it is a good quality cleaning rod that I use often.
I got this "one-piece" coated cleaning rod to help protect the bore during cleaning but the coating is starting to flake off near the patch-holder and at the screw joint.  It's really not "one-piece" because the patch holder screws onto the rod.  I don't know if the one I got just had a poor coating job or if the solvents are just too much for the coating.  I think I'll go with a carbon fiber rod in the future.  I also thought the 33" length would be plenty long but with at least one brand of bore guide in my Weatherby Vanguard S2 .30-06 the patch will not fully clear the end of the muzzle - works okay with another shorter brand of bore guide though.
After snapping the connecting ends off the cheap cleaning kit rod ends I got tired and just got a solid one for cleaning my rifle . I know I will not have to tilt my rifle to wiggle out the broken section of the cleaning rod out the end of the rifle ever again .  I bought 2 one to replace the one I broke at a friends house and one for myself . Great investment so far and it fits all of my bore brushes and mops except for my shotgun which uses bigger threads . I may have to get an adapter but that is neither here or there .
I learned that there is a difference between the short jags and the long jags.  The long ones were too tight to fit in my barrel, so I had to switch to the short ones.  The jag is sized correctly, the problem is that the patch you put around it will have some folds in it.  On these long jags, those folds increase the overall thickness too much.  You could probably cut the patches so they fit better, but that's a lot more trouble than just switching to a short jag.However, I discovered that these longer jags are just what the Dr ordered for cleaning the magazine tube.  So it wasn't a waste of money or anything.
Case was mislead because the picture does not show the clips. The case so far has no technical problems, it is however just not what I expected. It's small, but cheaply made, the clip mechanism is a snap-like action with no folds, so it reminds me of how ammo cases are folded. The package also took long to arrive. The case is overpriced for the quality, but nonetheless it hasn't broke down yetEDIT: after a year of using this case.  I regret buying it. and should've coughed up 2 extra dollars for a much better, more durable and reliable case. this case dries up my pistol, so do not use this if you have a metal frame gun.  i hate this case and have been using it to hold my art supplies instead.
I recently purchased a Bersa Thunder 380 and needed a lockable hard case for it.  Looked at a few options on Amazon and selected this case because of price and it had the Amazon Prime shipping option.  It actually arrived the next afternoon and I was able to fit the Bersa and two additional magazines in it (I attached a photo to the listing).  It is a sturdy case that closes easy and stays closed (I intentionally dropped it to see).  The pistol stays snug with the foam inserts.  Also the holes for the lock are in a good spot, easily accessible but not in the way.  If you are looking for a good case at a great price...this is the one.  My Taurus PT111 and one additional magazine fits (but I have another case for that one).
I bought this case for my new Ruger 1911 pistol.  The Ruger comes with a nice cloth carrying case with Ruger logo, but I wanted a hard case that would lock. I did not want to have to use the mandatory lock that is shipped with all firearms.  The case is too small for the Ruger 1911 which is the same size as any 1911 series pistol.  I have four magazines for the 1911 (after all the magazines that come with the pistol are only 8 rounds and 7 rounds).  The case would not close unless one pushed hard to close it with only one magazine in the pistol.  With three other magazines, it cannot close.  As for the product, it is OK.  It looks well made and it is Made in America.  I gave it three stars because it might work for smaller pistols, but not the 1911.  For a small pistol like a Ruger SR22, it would work great.
First off, I am NOT using this to store a gun.  I'm using it to store a shaver.  Regardless, I find the case quality lacking a bit. The latches are cheap feeling and don't have a positive action to them, and the &#34;hinge&#34; is not a hinge but rather a thin piece of plastic that WILL break after enough open/close cycles.  Comparing this to a Plano case, it's a night and day difference.  This will do OK storing my shaver but it's really rather disappointing considering similar offerings by Plano.  The reason I did not get the Plano (aside from the fact that I didn't expect the poor quality), is that I needed something smaller than their cases.
When I received the case it was a bit smaller than I expected but very accomodating. I fit my M&P; 22 which is the size of a standard M&P; pistol. My 1911 suprizingly also fit. They just fit nicely, no waisted space as shown in the description photo. I was very pleased.Outside 9.5" X 6.5" approximately, and inside 8.75" X 5.5" useable space. An additional magazine probably wouldn't fit with one of these larger guns however. A smaller pocket type pistol (Sig P238) would fit easy with an extra mag. Nice foam inside and secure latches.
I've been using Hoppe's products for more years that I will admit and have always been pleased with them. Of course their #9 is a classic, but their brushes, jags, rods and patches are all top quality as well. Sure other companies make good stuff too, but I know I'm not ever going to be disappointed with anything made by Hoppe's. Check out their new Viper bore snake, by the way. Just when you thought there wasn't anything new in gun-cleaning technology!
Daryl is most correct, cloth works much better than Hoppes synthetic.  Good cloth patches save time and you use less than you would of the synthetic ones.Years ago Hoppes use to be a terry cloth and they worked very well.  I still have some I purchased in the 1980's that were from the 1950's I found in a small hardware store with some new old stock cloth patches.  I purchased the Hoppes before I knew aboutButch's 3-Inch Square-10,12,16 Gauge Triple Twill Cleaning PatchesThese are the ones I use the most:Butch'S Twill Cleaning Patches (Bag Of 500) (2-1/4-Inch)The Hoppes are cheap in bulk and I now use them to clean the sound tube on Edison Model L M and A cylinder record player sound tubes, the Hoppes work well as you only need to remove dirt and oil.  At least they will not go to waste.
Can't beat Hoppe's quality. You might think "a patch is a patch." The last batch I bought were from another company and cheaper. "Good enough," I thought. Wrong. They were irregular in size and apparently made of varying rag stock. Some were soft and fluffy, others hard and not absorbent. Some had regular edges, others were frayed. This time, I spent a little more and got a consistent, high quality product. The Hoppe's patches are uniform, of good absorbency and of good firmness. That is elementary, but you get what you pay for, and the cheap patches were an annoyance and a poor pursuit of economy. Hoppe's patches do the job perfectly, and I don't notice them any more. I don't think that I am supposed to notice them.
I mostly use the spear type jags, as opposed to the slotted ones, and find that thicker patches are too tight fitting. For slotted jags, a bigger thicker patch is good. I've found that it's good to have an assortment of patches for different purposes. These are good for cleaning the bore with a spear type jag. Twill is strong and good for scrubbing internal parts. Flannel is soft and absorbent but can leave lint behind and is good for external parts. Anyway, that's how I use them.
The reviews here seem to be written by kind gentlemen who don't wish to sound harsh. But what they do say is quite a problem. These Hoppe's patches are way too small for the bores they say they are deigned for. These Hoppe's patches look like the same as the  &#34;Outers&#34; brand 17/.22 caliber patches but Hoppe's must be much thinner. I needed THREE .22/.270 caliber Hoppe's patches for each pass in my .223 caliber rifle. And I needed two and one half patches of the Hoppe's .270/.38 caliber patches to fit my .308 rifle. These tiny patches will cost you much more in the long run than the superior cotton patches from &#34;Pro-Shot&#34; that are sold here. If the Amazon word search here for &#34;gun patches&#34; (?) had shown the available Pro-Shot brands, I definitely would have ordered them and been very happy. As it is, I am not that pleased. Go for the Outers (better) or ProShot (best) brands.
Its obviously some synthetic material, not cotton.  It does fray if you catch it on something, then it just starts to fall apart.  It is also very thin.  Barely put a drop of CLP on it and it soaks the entire patch.  Not a huge fan of these.  Ended up buying these:Butch'S Twill Cleaning Patches (Bag Of 375)(2-1/2-Inch).Now I only use these to wrap it around a nylon brush when I scrub down the inside of the bolt area of the rifle (when the BCG is removed).  Works ok for that.
Otis, Hoppe&#8217;s, Kleenbore, and M-Pro 7 best names in the business for cleaning your handguns and long rifles.They make brushes, mops, patches, lead cloths, silicon cloths, and cleaners.Amazon has great prices.Here are my general steps every 250 rounds or so:I would use the M-Pro 7 cleaner and the brushes to loosen the gunk/lead from inside your barrel and other areas i.e. slide, gas piston...Then I use the the patches and mops to remove the gunk/lead from your gunI repeat the above steps  till spic n span.I might need the help of lead patches for those stubborn spots.I add a few tiny drop of lubricating oil (check your manual)Then I use your silicon cloth to clean the outside of the gun which adds a coat of silicone to prevent rust (check the finish of your gun first)
While I have not used the Hoppe's .38-.45 caliber patches yet, I just finished using the .22-.270 caliber size in my .223 rifle and the .270-.38 caliber size in my .308. THEY ARE REDICULOUSLY SMALL AND THEREFORE WASTEFUL. I needed 3 patches to feel any correct resistance in my .223, and 2.5 of the .270/.38 patches in my .308! Stick with the Pro-Shot cotton patches, also sold here as well. They will be far cheaper in the long run because you only need one patch per swipe instead of three.  Pro-Shot is best.....Outers is acceptable.....Hoppe's fail the test.

And end up with irregular shapes, loose strings, etc.  For a few bucks, you get a supply that will last a lifetime for some folks.  Even if you shoot often, 500 patches is going to last you a LONG time.  You could pay this much for a tiny bag of patches at a sporting goods store.  Good deal, exp. coming from the iconic name in gun cleaning.
