Back in the 1980's and earlier Hoppe's patches were cotton flannel, then they went to this cheap synthetic material.  You have to use two patches at a time because they are thin and do not absorb very well.  The only good thing about these is the price buying in bulk.Hoppes Gun Cleaning Patches, 38 to 45 CaliberYou could pay $2.60 + $5.54 shipping for 40 of these patches, here you get 500 for $7.37.  They are OK, but the cotton flanel ones like theAllen Company Gun Cleaning Patches (225 Pieces)for 30Cal, 357 Handgun to 45Calare much better.They are good for use as applicators when you do not want to waste a quality patch.
I ordered this on the 17th of April. It still hasn't arrived!!!!  Apparently, it takes OVER A WEEK to ship 1 item. Now I'm normally very patient with these things, but holy crap people. It's been 2 weeks!!!Other than that, I've used this product before. You'll need to oil or lubricate your firearm after using this but it does dry quickly and cleans well. Generally, I clean with oil, spray this stuff throughout and wipe down, then oil again. I'm fairly meticulous with cleaning my firearms though so you may not need to do this.
I like to clean up my Glock 21 4th generation and spray this stuff on the bottom of the slide and barrel assembly, and get a small squirt in the trigger group.  It sprays on wet, and blows out loose crap, but dries to a white finish.  The white finish is the dry lubricant, and it works well.  I treated my squeaky door hinges on my Jeep with this stuff and the squeaks went away.  Can't beat that.  And since it's a dry lube, it won't attract dust and dirt like wet lubricants will.  Best to stock up on this stuff because you never know when it's gonna be gone.
This stuff is the bomb. I use after cleaning my guns and putting them away. It leaves a protective oil on the gun which protects against rust. Your firearm will look like new after you use it. Also safe on polymer, plastic, and wood. One wipe will clean about 6-8 handguns or 2 rifles. My only complaint would be the price. Remington sells the same stuff in an aerosol spray which can be applied to a lint free cloth for a fraction of the cost.  But I also buy these wipes for portability and convince.
I purchased this product primarily because Remington recommends it (duh, I know!) for their model 870 20-gauge shotgun that I own.  I like the Rem Oil.  It seems to work quite well cleaning the shotgun.  I'm not crazy about the fact that the product is &#34;EXTREMELY FLAMMABLE&#34; and calls for wearing &#34;impermeable gloves&#34;.  Translation?  Toxic stuff!For my other firearms, I use the M-Pro 7 line of firearms cleaner and lubricant.  It is all inflammable and non-toxic.  So, that is the standard that I am personally measuring against.But as I wrote, the Rem Oil seems just fine for my Remington shotgun so all good there.
I like to use them after my range time to give a quick wipe to the pistol so it doesn't go in the bag totally dirty. When I do the strip cleaning and further clean the gun, it leaves the Teflon coat on the finish and don't quite like the look on the black so I further wipe with a blue towel or a micro fiber cloth before I put the weapon away. I'm going to buy the other brand just to compare.  I'll post my review when I'm ready.
These work well.  They're basically a soft, thin cloth material imbued with rem oil, the all-purpose cleaner/re-greaser from remington.  I'm not sure how much of a hit they take for cost-effectiveness versus a bottle of the stuff and your own wipes, but I feel they make up for it in convenience.  Also, easy to throw in a bag to take with for whatever reason.  They clean and grease well, and at the speed I work, generally stay moist/effective enough to clean one shotgun at a time.  I'm sure if you were more speed conscious you could fit in another long gun or handgun or two, but the grime does build up and you might want to switch anyway.  All-in-all I'm happy with these wipes and will probably purchase again.
I&#34;v read many articles and checked blogs and there is a lot of talk about how easily the remington tactical contracts rust.  With pump type application I think you don't waist as much as using the spray can.  I have the remington cleaning towel and I use the pump bottle to add a little more rem oil to the towel.  I haven't noticed any rust at all,  yet.  I suppose I'm a remington fan and I like everything remington to far.  But I&#34;m open minded to any product that does the job.
speaking from years of experience with many oils this one is good for the money but nothing special.to further explain it is a thin low viscous oil, good for base lube on a gun or knife sharpening.it is not as good as a thicker oil for rust prevention or heavy lube.this stuff also smells awful no idea how toxic it is but it smells like a weak solvent, however does not work for cleaning very well.bottom line wd40 does the same thing better for less, and is easier to get.for a real gun enthusiast you need a 3 in 1 clean, lube, protect break free is what pros use, kleen bore 3 in 1 is also good.some of my teachers recommend Smith&Wesson; oil it is also very good.simply put water is not the only thing that will mar your gun, you gotta watch for sand, dirt and other stuff.
I got a free sample of these with a firearm cleaning kit a while back, and I finally ran out, so time to get more.  They're great - reasonably strong material saturated with a nice lubricating oil, and more than enough to complete a job with one wipe.  They're good for much more than guns, though - anything that needs a light layer of oil to prevent rust and keep surfaces sliding smoothly against each other - hand tools, in particular seem to like these.  I'm still finding uses for them, and one wipe goes a long way.
This product is great! Does what it says and doesn't make a mess! It comes with a tube to fit on the spray nozzle so you can concentrate the Rem-Oil to your desired location! Rem-Oil will definitely decrease the wear on metal-to-metal contact.Pros:- Great cleaning and lubing solution!- Spray can comes with a plastic tube you can attach for more precise applications- You can use it for just about ANYTHING! (This product works so well, it will replace your WD-40!!!)Cons:- None (aside from price)Recommendation(s)/Suggestion(s):- Use this to lube just about everything! (No, not to be used on latex or humans (-_-"))In other words, this product is superb!
These Boresnakes are amazing, to put it simply. What used to take at least 30 minutes to an hour or so depending on the gun now only takes 5-10 minutes at most! The key is to make sure you get the cotton swab attachment that for some reason is not included with the Boresnake. That's the only downfall is the cotton swab attachment to finish up the cleaning. It does have the copper bristles to first scrub the barrel, then the entire length of the "snake" polishes, and the swab attached at the end with some lubricating oil finishes off the process. Do this two or three times, DONE! Even without the swab, it's an amazing item and a definite addition to you home or field cleaning kit.
The Good:  I buy these by the bushel and give them out like candy.  There is no way to say enough about these bore brushes.  I have been using them for over ten years, both in military and civilian capacities.  I recommend them 10/10 times.The Bad:  The only and very minor complaint is the wire brush part.  After prolonged usage, they can bend on you and become close to useless.  Unfortunately there is no real way to right them back up.  Regardless however, even with them slightly bent, the product works great.
Couldn't be easier to clean your rifle after a trip to the range with this boresnake.  I use this for my Mini 30 which shoots the 7.62x39 AK round.  Those rounds are notoriously dirty and some can be corrosive so cleaning your barrell after each shooting trip is critical.  While you still need to do more thorough clenaings of the reciever, bolt, gas block etc. this really works well for ongoing maintentnace.  It takes roughly 30 seconds to clean you barrell.  With it being that quick and easy I'm guessing I'll be a lot more willing to stay on top of routine clenaing needs.
I don't think I've met anybody that wasn't impressed by the Boresnake. It will totally change the way you clean your firearm. It brushes and wipes your barrel clean in a few quick easy motions. It may not be the best product if your firearm is filthy. You will probably have to get an old fashioned brush to scrub the gunk out. However, it does replace patches. One scrub with a Boresnake is equivalent to 5-6 old fashioned patches. This is great for maintenance cleaning. Get one. You won't be sorry.
My dad was a firearms dealer so I've been shooting 50+ years. I was raised to never put a firearm away until it was cleaned and lightly oiled even if only one round had been fired through it so I'm a bit OCD in this area. This Hoppe's BoreSnake is a great tool for cleaning my AR. It's compact and light weight so I can put it in a backpack or BOB for field cleaning without the need for all the rods and brushes. This is definately a must have tool for cleaning your firearms. As for my hand guns I still prefer to use rods and brushes because I actually enjoy taking my time cleaning them. It can be just as therapeutic as gardening.
It is pretty tight pulling this bore snake through a .22 rifle barrel, but it works.  I would expect that it needs to be tight to really get down into the rifling.  I did really have to force it, though, which was a bit of a pain.  It may begin to be easier the more I use it, so we'll see.  Other than that, i love the bore snakes.  i have one for my hunting rifle as well, and it really beats slamming the rods and patches down the barrel over and over to get it clean.  Great tool, very useful.
Bore snakes are fantastic. I have one in every caliber I shoot, and even a couple I don't. They are great for a quick clean in between shooting sessions when I don't want to break out the hoppes and patches. I use it every time I shoot my milsurp rifles soaked in windex, as the primers in surplus ammo are often corrisive. If it gets too dirty I just throw them in a laundry bag along with some dirty rags and my mechanic gloves in a small wash cycle. Well worth the small cost for the great utility.
This would be a must have for any rifle other than a corrosive firing non chromed barrel Mosin Nagant.  I religiously clean the barrels after shooting my Mosin's and it takes forever.  So I bought this to cheat and save a ton of time.It partially worked, cleaning out the barrels pretty decently.  BUT after a week I went back and checked, sure enough it does not get very single bit of grime out of the barrel and they had a light coating or rust starting.Now I used it initially to get the majority of the crud out of the barrel then run a few patches down after words.  It DOES cut down on cleaning time and would be all you need for a chromed lined modern rifle. But with the old WW-2 Era bolt rifles without a chromed barrel, make sure you check a few days later that you do not have rust forming.
This bore cleaner is very well constructed and looks like it will stand up to a lot of use - which you would expect from a Hoppes brand product.  The materials used are high quality and the product works very well.  Makes the chore of cleaning the barrel a quick and easy task.  A weighted tip pulls the cord down the barrel making getting the cleaner in place very easy.  The cord is plenty long and the loop in the opposite end of the cleaner makes it very easy to draw the cleaner back and forth through the barrel for a thorough cleaning.  Only complaint is that the instructions are nonexistent.  If you do not know how to use a bore snake you will be in the dark. I would definitely purchase this product again.
I have a 1934 Mosin Nagant that I regularly shoot surplus corrosive ammo. You MUST clean the gun after shooting to save the bore and mine has about the nicest I have seen ever for an old surplus gun. It used to take me hours, cleaning the bore and the chamber with a brush and patches, but now I just yank the bolt, use a mop on the chamber and bore, let it soak for a minute, brush the chamber, run the snake down the bore twice, patch once to check everything and I am DONE. Saves me at least 1/2 hour (I keep my guns very clean and happy)
I use these before shooting and just after shooting in all of my firearms. These are great product and I wish that they had come around sooner.For my Mosin Nagant, and when firing corrosive ammunition, I normally use two of these immediately after a shooting session; one is soaked in Windex with ammonia to saturate the barrel and neutralize the corrosive residue and a second soaked in Ballistol to help protect the barrel until I can get it a more thorough cleaning. I keep them in my shooting bags so that I always have them with me for a shooting session.I can throw them in a sock and toss them into the washer for cleaning. If you own a firearm, you really need this product.
I purchased this to clean my ruger 10/22 since it can only be cleaned from the muzzle end. I apply solvent, in this case Hoppes 9, let it sit for 5 minutes while I service the rest of the weapon then I run this bore snake through two times, then apply more solvent and run it through again twice.You take the brass weight and drop it through wherever you wish to clean, and pull the snake through.Good product, I wish it were US made, it is made in China.
Many reviewers made this seem like a bloody miracle.  It may just be that we're shooting completely different stuff.  I shoot a lot of older stuff (91/30 Mosin Nagant, VZ.24 Mauser, Type 99 Arisaka) and I love this because it is so compact I can take it in my range bag and run it through a few times right after shooting.  I do not see a specific patch section of the bore snake, though perhaps they are counting the rest of the body of the snake for that.  I may tie in a couple of strips of cloth to get a tighter fit for that function.I still use my Dewey rods on the barrel and do a full break down and cleaning (I'm shooting corrosive ammo) when I get home, but this does a great job for an initial cleaning.
This product is great. It is a must have for anyone who shoots a lot. I can use this at the range to keep proper function and tight groups. It really cuts down on cleaning time.I know others have stated that they don't think it scrubs the bore good enough, I do agree with that after a long shooting session. But what I do is use a regular bore brush if it needs it and the boresnake as well in place of patches.  The boresnake works much better than any patch I have ever used and it is reusable. It is great to have for hunting when a shot may not be taken or only a couple shots are down the barrel.For the price amazon is selling them for it is worth having around even if you do want to keep your old bore brush as well. I don't have to worry about running out of patches, having to find or cut the right patch size, or taking more than a mInute to maintain a unfired or slightly dirty firearm.
Hoppe's makes the best boresnake on the market, bar none. I had a snake made by another company, whose name I will not mention, that did not a terrible job of removing fouling. I now use it solely to apply lubricant to the barrel. A few run throughs with the Hoppe's boresnake, however, and the black crap came right out of my Mosin with no fuss. It's the brass bristles that make the difference, they really grip and scrub out lead and carbon fouling without damaging the barrel. The wide cloth end for soaking up solvent (I use Hoppe's No. 9) wipes the scrubbed out gunk out and leaves the bore nice and shiny. I will buy one of these for my shooting buddy come Christmas.
And it works great, I figured I could overlook the 0.3 difference. Boresnakes are great, somebody had a great idea and I wish it had been me. Makes cleaning barrels incredibly fast and easy. I'll use a boresnake and then clean the barrel again with a patch or vice versa, just because I enjoy cleaning up at the end of the day, but this has everything you'd want or need in one pass through the barrel. Very clever and efficient. Gotta admire that. It takes longer to gather this thing up to put it away than it does to use it, really.
My son has been trying to get me to buy one of these for a long time but I am an old rod and patch person and thought there was no other way to completely clean the bore of a gun.  I finally purchased one of these and I am impressed.  It really does the job, especially out in the field when you need to do a quick cleaning and caint carry all the accessories needed to do it right.  I also use this in conjunction with wetting down the bore with solvent and soaking, then use the bore snake to remove the fouling.  It works like a dream.  I have one of these for every caliber now.
This little boresnake is great for .22lr rifles, especially the Ruger 10/22.  With that rifle, you must clean from the muzzle to the receiver when using a traditional rod and patch.  This is not ideal as you can damage the crown of the muzzle.With a boresnake, however, you can clean from the receiver and exit the muzzle.  Quick, easy, and does the job on the Ruger 10/22.I gave this 4 stars instead of 5 simply because I think this should sell for approximately $12.
This Bore Snake has a sort of nylon brush in the center rather then the brass on used on fire arms. It does a great job and much easer to use then cleaning pellets. No chance of scratching the barrel, works much better then a rod.Air Gun barrels are made of a softer metal then Fire Arms so using a conventional boar snake is not a good idea for air guns. This is a great solution.I also use this in my .22 air rifle as it seems to do a good job with them also.
I use bore snakes for both pistols and long rifles...After forty years of using the "classic" rod, brush, patch system of cleaning 1911 .45s, M-16s, M-60s, .22 rifle, 9 mm pistols, .308 and 30-06 rifles, using ANY other method is simply a non starter...  The bore snake is simple, reliable, and much less hassle for routine cleaning.One thing that is different about the bore snake is that it is a bit messy to handle during and after use, so I use rubber gloves when cleaning weapons, and store the bore snake in a Ziploc bag....
Bore snakes work so well!  I must have 10 of them around.  This price was way better than I could find locally.  Bore Snakes will make you pack all your bending/breaking/scratching metal cleaning rods up and put them in a box to be forgotten.  2 pulls of a bore snake is like monkeying around with dirty smelly patches and a metal rod that scratches your barrel's crown for an hour.  Dip the wire brush part at the front in Hoppe's bore solvent, put a few drops of Mobile 1 along the long fat swap part works great.  Mobile 1 works great and is much cheaper than tiny bottles of thin "magic potion" oil.
These BoreSnakes have been around for a while now, and it's such a simple design.  It's an improvement on the old "pull-string" barrel cleaning methods that required the user to clean the barrel in separate steps RE pull-through the bore brush, then pull-through the cleaning patch.  This BoreSnake does it all at one time.  It's also good because it allows the user to clean his/her firearm from chamber-to-muzzle, which is preferable to cleaning from muzzle-to-chamber, which lessens the chances of pulling dirt/grime/etc. back into the chamber area.One note - if using this 5.56 BoreSnake in an AR type rifle, you'll still need to clean the locking-lug area with a military type chamber brush because the BoreSnake can't clean that particular area.  However, it does a fast and great job with the AR's chamber and barrel.  A very worthwhile purchase.
I have used Boresnakes for years for my handguns and rifles, of all calibers. Except, until now, .22LR.I managed to get it about 1/4 of the way into the bore, but it wouldn't budge any further. The nylon leader began to break, so I 'backed it out' and took it back to the vendor (not Amazon.com).You might have a different experience in .22LR, but this was just a tight squeeze, and I'll stick with the cleaning rod, pull through, jag and patches.In other calibers these work fine, but they should be thoroughly washed with every use, or else you're just dragging old junk through the barrel again.
These bore snakes are much easier to use and cause much less damage to the barrel than your traditional push rod and brush. I find that I can spray in, or simply add a few drops of, bore cleaner into the barrel and allow it to soak in for a few minutes and then just pull this through a few times and the bore is clean.  An extra wet patch sometimes if I have gone a few days from when I last shot the gun. I have them in multiple calibers and they all seem to work equally well.
Okay, I'll admit that there is still certainly a place for the ever-useful cleaning patch, but the bore snake is a huge time saver without sacrificing the quality of cleaning. In fact, it seems to me that the bore snake gets the bore cleaner than multiple patches ever did. These snakes are super easy to use, and provide the tightness and lots of surface to really scrub the bore clean. What's more, for rifles that don't allow access to the breech for a long cleaning rod - you can now properly clean them in the right direction (breech to muzzle). And, the snake is washable for a long life of continued use.
I am a trained military armorer, an NRA instructor, a military competition shooter and someone who just plain enjoys shooting guns. Not cleaning them so much, mostly shooting them. There are books written about different ways to clean guns and I won't go into that here.I am firmly in the 'clean the carbon leave the copper' camp. The Boresnake lets me do that and quickly. Its not a replacement for a actual stiff cleaning rode, which you should always have around for different reasons like stuck cases. But I can take a brake at a match or sniper course, run a Boresnake through my rifle and be ready to get back on line in minutes. They work great, take up no room and stow anywhere. When using one you should poor your cleaning solvent onto the forward part of the snake and not dig it to prevent contamination. That said it gets done what its made for, nothing fancy or super special. But its reliable, inexpensive and super easy to use. Every shooter should have one.
This works great for my Marlin Model 60.  Some people do not care for bore snakes, but I personally do not mind that they do not get my gun surgically clean.  The trade off for me is ease of use.  Dab some CLP or other solvent directly onto the snake above the bristle section and pull through three times, good to go.  When these things start to get filthy, you can either wash them by hand with soap and hot water, or put them in a sock and toss them in the washing machine.
I have multiple Boresnakes and as my title suggests they do work quite well and really help while at the range and want a quick spruce-up of your weapon.Now I have also bought a cleaning kit for each of my calibers as well, for nothing is quite as satisfying to my OCD with my firearms than a clean white patch coming out of the barrel.If you've only shot a few rounds at the range this thing is awesome, but if your gun is really soiled, you have a brass build-up, or you just want to zen out and clean your gun then go with regular kits.  It's hard to tell with a Boresnake if the barrel is clean or not, for they are usually a dark color.  But again, still a very good product and will continue to purchase them.
We use Hoppe's No. 9, cloth patches and bronze brushes for the really deep cleanings before storage, but we use Hoppe's bore snakes for quick cleanings in between.  They are well made, fit in your pocket or gun kit, and last for years.  Each one is stamped with the proper caliber so you can grab the right one.  The weight on one end drops it down the barrel, and the handle on the other end gives you a firm grip when pulling it in and out.Using a bore snake polishes out gun powder residue, protecting your barrel from pitting, and improves your accuracy by removing any gunk that would interfere with the bullet trajectory.  When your bore snake gets dirty, just hand wash it, and you're good to go.Every gun enthusiast should have a Hoppe's bore snake for each caliber weapon he or she fires.
I don't like the viper version much, I think it's just inflated pricing.Anyway, I always use gun scrubber on my barrel, then I scrub (with bronze brush) my barrel vigorously.Then I use rem-oil, spray down my barrel (ensuring the gun scrubber stuff is washed out) and again scrub my barrel.Finally, i'll put a bit of Hoppe's elite gun oil on the bristle part of this product and run it through my barrel a few times.Lastly i'll inspect with a bore light, and repeat this process as necessary until I have a spotless barrel.That being said, a boresnake is an essential part of barrel cleaning nowadays and essentially replaces barrel cleaning cloths. Boresnakes also do a much better job at &#34;detailing&#34; a barrel, making it shiny (for chrome lined barrels) and spotless.This works on 7.62x39 barrels (i.e. AK barrels)
I use this for my Ruger 10/22 rifle, 22 inch barrel, my Ar-15's ( Colt and M&P Sport-15, 5.56) and my SR22 pistol. Com'on, it's a no brainer to clean with these snakes. It takes up to 30 seconds to scrub, clean and polish/ wipe dry your barrels. get rid of the cleaning rods. I am a consumer, not a dealer.  I have purchased 5 different caliber sizes including a 12 gauge shotgun. when you get it, you will no doubt see the huge advantage of having them.
Not too sure why I haven't seen one before, but as soon as I did I got it on my Christmas list. I used it to break in a new .308 and it cut my break in period to about 1/2 the time. The biggest benefit is that my barrel is now broken in and not broken by traditional style "bore guides" or cleaning rods, cumbersome patches etc.After some research on barrel break in the No. 1 biggest problem is YOU, the person breaking the barrel in by beating scratches into it with a cleaning rod. The bore snake eliminates this and saves time doing it.Compare $25 for boresnake to $250-500 for a new barrel after your gunsmith tells you why you can't shoot under 1 moa because you screwed your barrel right up by banging it over the head with a cleaning rod 25 times.
What can I say, it's a BoreSnake, it does the job. Not as thorough as a standard cleaning rod with patches but in most cases it is good enough for a light day at the range or a routine maintenance-cleaning of stored guns. If I have a heavy day at the range I usually run this BoreSnake through a couple times with CLP to get the big stuff and then finish-up with a standard cleaning rod. I would highly recommend. I also have these in 9mm and 12 gauge. (I will say that for some reason my 30 caliber BoreSnake is not as tight to the bore as my other ones)
Jamming a metal rod down your bore is the old fashioned way to clean a barrel.  The problem is that if you are not careful, you can mess up the crown which will in turn affect your accuracy downrange.Boresnakes are pretty awesome for cleaning purposes without the risk of messing up your barrel.  I will say this, make sure you use the right size snake in your barrel or risk getting it stuck to all heck.For me, I typically toss some Hoppes #9 on the copper brush, and some oil on the trailing side of the snake, and run it through a couple times.  Get it nice and clean and lubed in a couple of passes.Plus, I'm sure you can toss the snake in the wash.  I haven't yet though and after a dozen or more cleanings, it works just a nice as when new.
I have BoreSnakes for nearly all of my guns and absolutely love them.  Haven't bought one for my muzzleloader yet.  They get so filthy I may stick with patches.For all my regular rifles, shotguns and handguns they work great.  Some basic recommendations though.  Be sure to pull them from the chamber to the tip of the barrel so you don't deposit the gunk in the firing mechanism.  You also need to be careful needing them in until the bristles are inside the barrel so you don't scour and damage the outside finish.  I have a friend that sprays Rem Oil on the BoreSnake so it can clean and lube at the same time.  It works very well but I don't care for the overspray that gets on the table nor do I want the mess to carry around in the field.  If I thought ahead to take a baggie or was at home where I could wash it out it wouldn't be bad.These are excellent products!
I have been cleaning firearms for over 40 years and have never had a better aid for doing it right than the Boresnake. I have an aversion to putting a firearm away without cleaning it if it's been fired, and sometimes it seems a bit of a bother. With this gadget, half the work is taken out of the equation, and with the proper lubes, brushes and an air compressor with a nozzle (my personal secret for getting grit and dust out of hard to reach places!) the rest of the job is easy.

I put some CLP on the brushes and run the snake through the breach end of the barrel once or twice...job done. The BoreSnake makes cleaning a much faster task, and that's a good thing especially when not at home with my work bench and gear. The 'Snake goes in my range bag and heads out on trips with me to be the primary cleaner when away from home.I used this first on .223/5.56 AR-15 and must say that it was an extremely tight fit - so much so that I was worried about damage to the chrome lined barrel. After reading more on the 'net I put a ton more gun oil on and that helped a lot. Still have to give it a very strong pull through the barrel, but it seems to do a very good job.Still give my firearms a good rod & patch cleaning at home every once in a while, but the 'Snake will do in between those times.
I really like the Hoppe's Boresnakes for cleaning my guns.  I already had boresnakes for my shotguns and  pistols but this one is for my 22 rifle.  I expect it will do the same easy cleaning that is less messy and faster than any other cleaning method I've used.  There are no rods to attack together, no tips to change, no box of pads to use and dispose of after, none of the drips on the floor or other hassles that happen with cleaning rods.  You just drop in the brass weight and pull the rest of the snake through the barrel.  You can add oil to the tail of the snake and reoil  if you wish.  The built in brass brush cleans and the rest of the snake polishes.  It doesn't get easier.
A bore snake simplifies cleaning and makes the job quicker.  I have used this one on both .22LR and .223 Rem / 5.56 NATO rifles with great results.  Simply drop the weighted end through the bore, squirt some CLP or whatever you choose to clean the barrel, and pull it through.  Repeat a couple of times and the barrel is clean.When the bore snake is dirty, simply throw in the sink with hot water and gentle detergent, agitate briefly, and rinse with clean water.  Now it is ready for the next cleaning job.
I wet the section in front of the bristles with Hoppe's #9 and the tail section with CLP for a complete bore cleaning. I run it through 3-4 times and it scrubs out any leading or copper fouling and leaves the bore with a thin layer of oil when I'm done. I prefer this much more than a rigid rod that can cause damage to the breach. After 3-4 uses it gets washed in the washing machine and then hung over a closet door to dry and it's ready for service again.
I am not a professional gun person - I am rather new to the hobby and enjoy shooting!  But when it comes to cleaning my guns I have tried a few different tools and have mostly been disappointed.  Until now.  This is so easy to use, durable, cleans well and is just about perfect in my mind.  So very glad I made this investment!!!  I purchased different sizes for the different guns I have.  They are easy to store and easy to use.  Highly recommended.
In my opinion, bore snakes are a must when cleaning.  I don't recommend this to be the ONLY method to cleaning but should be a supplement to the cleaning rod and patches.I typically use the bore snake after the rod and patches to make sure I really purge whatever junk is in the barrel.  Then I would run a light coat of oil afterwards.  That may seem excessive to some but with the possible threat to our gun rights nowdays, we must take good care of the wonderful firearms that we have!

I had a training class with some coworkers and noticed someone using one of these bore snakes. He was able to clean his rifle barrel far faster than anyone using the brass rod. At first I figured he just did a terrible job, but decided to look into these anyway.I ordered this to try out and I couldn't be happier with it. It's a much better alternative to the old way of cleaning. I ordered it in .223 and it was a perfect fit for my rifle. I'll definitely be ordering more of these in my other calibers.

Fits perfectly,  drop the weight,  catch it at the muzzle pull and then pull back from the chamber,  I only do it 3 times.  Snake has some serious little spikes.  See my review for CLP. I love these boresnakes, not sure what else there is to say.  I have one for each caliber I own, and use them regularly.  They are great for the field, and quick and easy to use for a field-strip cleaning.  Still need to do a thorough cleaning periodically, but this really takes a lot of stress out of a quick range day.  They also wash in the clothes washer (wouldn't suggest putting them in with any clothes), and the one I've had the longest has held up for several years of regular use.  Will continue to buy these products as needed.

One pass loosens large particles, scrubs out the remaining residue with a bronze brush, then swabs it all spotless with a cleaning area 160x larger than a standard patch.&#34;&#34;Add a few drops of Hoppe&#8217;s No 9 Lubricating Oil or Hoppe&#8217;s Elite Gun Oil and your gun&#8217;s ready for storage.&#34;&#34;The world&#8217;s quickest, three-step bore shine.Extremely packable.Available for rifles, shotguns and pistols.Brass weight on the pull cord is stamped with the size.Machine washable.Patented one-piece design.&#34;
I have one of these for my AR15 5.56/.223 Bushmaster and cleaning the barrel is now quik and easy and no fear of scratching the chrome lined bore!!!  So I watched a youtube video on the same theory for cleaning by Ruger Black Hawk Elite .177/1200 fps break barrell, I used this awesome tool for my rifles first cleaning, ran it through three times, man it was so clean, after the first time the second and third time the bore litterally squeeked it was so clean, didn't have to use cleaning pellets or risk a solvent that could damage my rubber O-Ring in the breach!! I have always loved to clean my guns after a good day of shooting but I'm always on the look out for new and better methods.  A friend recommended the bore snake and it truly is a godsend.  I simply run solvent completely down the barrel and let it sit while I clean the rest of the weapon.  Then, I simply run the bore snake through the barrel toward the muzzle and pull through, it's really that simple.  Couldn't be happier and would definitely buy again.
I like the idea of the bore snake and it does a decent job as long as you're not expecting it to do the same job as a traditional cleaning. It's super fast and convenient to use and the barrel is nice and shiny after a single pass. A couple of passes with some CLP and it should be plenty clean enough if you're just going to turn around and shoot again in a few days. If you're cleaning it prior to longer term storage, etc. I'd highly recommend a traditional cleaning because the bore snake simply doesn't get all of the carbon gunk, etc. that a rod and pads will get. That's been my experience anyway. Great for what it does though.
I am a perfectionist, especially when it comes to firearms.  Maybe it's my military background, but I like my stuff clean after every use.  I enjoy cleaning and disassembling my weapons, and this just saves so much time.  I take a dry toothbrush and then a brush with rubbing alcohol to my weapons.  Then I soak the barrel in CLP.  While that works, I wipe down the rest of the firearm with rags and patches.  I've also recently started trying chamber stars, which fit in and behind the locking lugs - a bit expensive, but save time any clean places otherwise impossible to get to.  When thats done, I run the bore snake through the barrel about 10-15 times, in less than a minute.  I then reapply oil to the essential components and am all done.  The bore snake takes about 15mins less time than brushes and patches did.
A friend recommended these products to me, and I have to say he was absolutely right.  I use this on my Remington Model 597 plinker rifle and it just takes a few pulls with some oil and solvent to keep the bore sparkling clean and deposit free between firings.  I would recommend giving the bore a good scrubbing with a soft metal wire cleaning tool first, as the bristles on this aren't as densely placed.  You don't have to do this, but it reduces the number of pulls through the bore you'll need to clean the firearm.  I gave this model a 4/5 only because the fit is very snug for a .22 cal bore.  It feels like I have to put a lot more tension to draw this through the bore than I do for any other BoreSnake I own.  It may perhaps be better suited for .223/5.56 bores.
I like this sling a lot, and the quality is high but it's not as easy to adjust as they make it sound. I can make it longer with one hand but making it shorter takes two. Also, it would be nice if it was a little longer, and while they do give you instructions on how to lengthen it, it only adds about two inches. The attached swivels look well made and are easy to take on and off. Overall a nice sling, unless you're a big guy.
So I specifically purchased these patches to clean my guns after range use.  I paid more for these because I wanted an absolute lint free patch, that would not leave traces of lint on my gun after cleaning.  Well, I still havent found the right patch.  When I clean the outside of my black gun with oil, these patches leave lint on the gun.  I then have to get a microfiber cloth to wipe of the residue from the patches.  These dont absorb oil like other patches, but they are strong.
The first time I fed this thing through the barrel and started yanking on it, I really thought it was going to snap because it fit so tight.  But then I realized, if its not tight its not going to cleaning everything.  When out in the field, whether you are lazy or just did not bring all your cleaning gear, this BoreSnake and a small bottle of cleaning solution will get you through your day of shooting.  I will agree with the other reviewer that cleaning rods and patches do a better thorough job, however.
I already own a Boresnake for the 9mm pistol and was completely sold on its performance. The 12 gauge versiondoes not disappoint at all.Keep in mind the Boresnake is not meant to replace a rod and barrel brush along witha reliable cleaner.I run it through the barrel 3 or 4 times then proceed with my regular cleaning routine(I follow itwith rod and brush with Mpro 7 and some Shooter's Choice).A must have for any cleaning kit.Best of all,once it gets excessivelysoiled, wash and reuse. Fabrics bag in the washer will get it done.Outstanding product.
My wingmaster's barrel has never been cleaner. Just put a little bit of oil around the diameter towards the end, and pull it through 2-3 times and you are DONE. Fast, cheap, and effective. Can't ask for more. I have one in .22 that was much harder to pull through the first time, but the 12 gauge one wasn't bad at all. I will keep buying these as I acquire new calibers.They also wash when dirty, just a little bit of soap and some hot water, then let them air dry and you are good to go.
The first time I ever used a bore snake, I had my doubts.  After all, I've been cleaning firearms (large and small) with a rod, for years.  But the first time I used a Hoppe's boresnake, I knew that I would never, ever go back to using a rod.  Boresnakes generally get the barrel clean with ONE PASS, don't scratch the bore, and are easy to clean and reuse.  And, as always, if it's says &#34;HOPPE'S&#34; on the label, there's quality to spare.
I know it's not the equivalent of a serious tear-down cleaning, but it doesn't seem to be all that far from it.  I have a short-barrel shotgun for home defense purposes which I fire infrequently, usually at a local range.  A good hose-down with an all purpose cleaner+protectant spray, followed by a pass through the barrel with this snake seems to clear the barrel of what little crud got deposited there during a practice session.  Those who use their shotguns a lot, say for hunting, will probably want to use more stringent methods from time to time, but this is great for a quick cleaning.
I give the device 5 stars, I had two others before I got this one---and they are great.HOWEVER--I wanted to try the newer, Viper version for my 20 Gauges--(I have several)So I searched Amazon and found it in 12 gauge, but there was an option menu box, where I chose 20 gauge and placed order for what i assumed was the 20 gauge Viper version of the boresnake.When the unit arrived, it was just the standard version--not the Viper-- I like the piece and will use it, so I didn't return it---BUT it isn't what I thought I was getting.
This is a great product.  Takes many minutes off your gun cleaning tasks.  Also saves on supplies, such as patches, solvents, and other cleaners/lubricants.  For people who shoot different guns and calibers the Boresnake makes cleaning a cinch.  I use the Boresnake and the Boresnake Viper for different guns.  The Boresnake Viper does provide better cleaning one the first couple of runs, but both are more than adequate.  I'm not sure how these work with "dirty ammo", but with range reloads and factory ammo, it works great!
What can I say, it's a BoreSnake, it does the job. Not as thorough as a standard cleaning rod with patches but in most cases it is good enough for a light day at the range or a routine maintenance-cleaning of stored guns. If I have a heavy day at the range I usually run this BoreSnake through a couple times with CLP to get the big stuff and then finish-up with a standard cleaning rod. I would highly recommend. I also have these in 9mm and 30 caliber.
I'm not lazy when it comes to cleaning guns. I'll do it the old fashioned way with brushes, patches, Hoppe's #9 and a rod if that's what it takes. But this is a great additional tool that does a lot of that in one pass. It's very sturdy and well made. The brush part is exceptional. Plus you can put some oil on the end and lightly lubricate your barrel at the same time. I cleaned a 12-guage in no time with some foaming bore cleaner, a dab of CLP and this. Easy as can be.
Why get huge kits when you can get one for each gauge. I have a Mossberg 500 and I will just run this one to three times depending on how much I fired. Easy to use means you will do it more and I say that is worth its weight in gold. It made sense to me especially since it is kinda like a paintball gun squeegee or on a paintball gun pushing paper towel through very tightly. I read a bunch of straight pipe loyalists. Maybe for marksmen and high end guns but for me and my brother, whom hunts around the country many different animals, uses many guns, and hardly ever cleans his guns............we will stick with this. Most important is to keep your gun dry off after use.
I dip the front of it in kerosene and run it through the barrel (always in the direction of the bullet/shot) and it leaves the bore with a mirrior finish. Shotgun brushes, rods, and patches are oversized and rather slow to change, like any rod kit.Being a boresnake, it works a hundred times better than patches since there is so much more contact with the bore. I wouldn't pack this into a field cleaning kit though, it's huge.Snags easier on parts inside the receiver than rifle boresnakes, especially a Saiga 12.Would recommend to anyone active with shotguns.
In my opinion, bore snakes are a must when cleaning.  I don't recommend this to be the only method to cleaning and should be a supplement to the cleaning rod and patches.I typically use the bore snake after the rod and patches to make sure I really purge whatever junk is in the barrel.  Then I would run a light coat of oil afterwards.  That may seem excessive to some but with the possible threat to our gun rights nowdays, we must take good care of the wonderful firearms that we have!
I have several bore snakes and I love them all. It's an easy way to clean your barrel and I like that I'm always running the brush from the chamber towards the muzzle. If I were to make any changes to it I would like to see a couple more wire brushes built into it instead of only one. I guess they will come out with that idea in a &#34;new and improved version&#34; sometime in the future. I have three for each caliber. What I do is use one for applying a harsh cleaning solution, one for a less harsh solution and one for a light coat of oil. I saturate the last 3-4&#34; of the snake and pull it slowly through the barrel to coat the inside before in storage..
A friend recommended these products to me, and I have to say he was absolutely right.  I use this on my Mossberg 500 pump and it just takes a few pulls with some oil and solvent to keep the bore sparkling clean and deposit free between firings.  I would recommend giving the bore a good scrubbing with a soft metal wire cleaning tool first, as the bristles on this aren't as densely placed.  You don't have to do this, but it reduces the number of pulls through the bore you'll need to clean the firearm.  The pull string is more than long enough to easily draw this through the 28 inch field barrel I use.
This speed loader pouch is tough, thick, and hard, perfect for reinsertion of spent speed loaders (which I don't see happening in a firefight). This strength is also its weak point. The hardness of it makes it uncomfortable when I bump into the wall; the damn thing digs into my love handles. Other than this, it holds a six-round speed loader for a Ruger GP-100 perfectly well with no rattle. I tried a 5-round speed loader for my SP-101 and it rattles like a snake out in the desert. Other than these small issues, it is a great speed loader pouch.
I bought  this to hold HKS 36-A Speedloaders for my CCW. This works perfectly. With the rigid sides it is easy to get the loader in and out quickly without catching like the soft ones. It is a bit bulky and since I carry a 38 there is some rattle from the extra room my loaders have but from under my shirt I don't notice it. Also it takes some getting use to since it is very stiff, I have trouble moving it around my belt to get a comfortable position when driving.
I purchased two Safariland J-GL8C COPMII speedloaders for a Ruger GP100, and needed a case to hold them. This case works perfectly at holding the speedloaders in place. When the snap is released the loader won't "fall" out as the case is designed to hold the loader snugly. This case must have a belt looped through it, which is fine. A nice alternative would be a clip on version, as one wouldn't have to place the case in the anterior or posterior position of a belt loop. I would (and have) recommend this case to anyone interested in buying a speedloader case.
I use this for my .357 rounds, the pouch is pretty well built and tough for leather. Though, it is leather so it will scratch pretty easily but that's not something I care about. I use this pouch when I dress for work.My Speedloaders are HKS made also, six-shot loaders. They don't rattle too much, if you were to run you'd hear them bounce around but if you're walking it won't annoy you. Also, the belt loop is very tight. The width that it allows for belts prevents it from moving up and down your belt. It's very comfortable even when you're sitting also (whether at work or driving).  Overall, this is a damn good speedloader pouch. I have no complaints so far.Just remember the part about the leather, they will get scuffed up eventually - just like good shoes. Polish!
I am in Alaska.  They say that the .44 mag is the perfect bear gun, but a lightweight revolver is darn near impossible to find. I went with the .44 special bulldog.  It's light and it may not be a mag, but it will work.  I bought two speed loader which gives me 15 rounds. These fit on my belt by my holster within easy reach and I have not bumped or brushed into them causing any problems when I motorcycle offroad. The snaps are solid but easy to pop.  This worked for me.
Using cold blue on a firearm you plan on using and taking in and out of pistol rugs and holsters is about useless. I applied 7 coats of cold blue to my firearm and it showed 'wear' nearly immediately with only a few of the above actions executed. If you wanted to cold blue a firearm for the wall as a display this would be excellent. The color was dark and looked great. Otherwise, if it is an 'in use' practical firearm, spend the money and take it to a gunsmith for proper blueing. I did not get to try the wood refinish yet.
I am in the process of refinishing a double barrel 12 gauge that I sawed off at 18.25&#34; and so far have only reblued the barrel and I am very happy with how it came out.  It looks like it is brand new, and the instructions were easy to follow.  I have not refinished the stock yet but I am expecting that part to go just as well as the blueing.  The only thing I would change is it would be nice if it came with some fine steel woal, but I got by just fine with a brass dish scrubbing pad.
If you're professionally blueing, this kit won't last long.  But if you're like me and it's touch-ups and minor jobs, then this is perfect.  The products are all top notch and easy to use.  The results are easily professional quality, as long as you follow all the directions (which are not hard to understand).  I'm pretty much a novice, but the one full pistol I re-blued looks absoulutely fantastic, and more than a few folks have asked me where I got it done.  I tell them I used this kit, and they were pretty impressed.  I'm really happy with it.
Works great. Used it on an old cheap revolver I recently purchased, and it's given it a new life! Warning: won't blue stainless steel, aluminum or other non-ferrous metals. Also, if you don't know how to blue a gun then you should REALLY Google up some instructions or watch a video on Youtube. Blueing is essentially a controlled corrosion of the metal. You need to clean the area BEFORE you blue and then you need to clean and oil it AFTER the process or else the finished product is either going to look like crap... or your gun is going to rust the next day. You've been warned. Now, like I said, this is a good product and highly recommend it.
This worked great. I used some rust remover which took the blue off. Dumb me. Ordered this, used the rust remover to remove all blue. I think you will be forced to do two coats for uniformity. As I recall I did three coats. No one could tell the guns have been re-blued. I bought a used gun with a rub mark. I know where it is so I can see it. You would not. Touch up is tricky so I could do better if I do it again but I was very pleased. I then touched up more of my guns.
I purchased this set of hangers to display an antique rifle in my office.  The installation was easy into a wood panelled wall.  I think installation into drywall would require special fasteners which do not come with the hangers.  The finish looks to be polished brass but not polished to a mirror finish.  They are thick material and very strong so that if they are fastened to the wall securely they should be able to hold significant weight.These hangers are attractive but do not overwhelm the object being displayed.  All in all, I'm quite satisfied with this purchase.
I have now bought 5 sets of these hangers and they fit my cabin decor perfectly.  They have a quality look and are lined with leather to prevent scratching the guns.Only difficulty with the product is that the screws mount into slots on either side rather than into holes through the hanger.  It just makes it a little more difficult to mount trying to position the screws to either side properly.  Would have been much easier with a hole on either side rather than a slot.  That is a small inconvenience in the mounting and once mounted it is a handsome way to display your rifles or shotguns.
I wanted to like this a lot.  Turns out it's merely ok.  When you push the button OMG HERE COMES HOPPES #9.  It's great for those hard to reach places when you don't mind a puddle of Hoppes.  But it's definitely not for precision work.  I'm puzzled by the reviewer who complained about the smell. It smells like Hoppes #9.  Works like Hoppes #9.  Three stars for function.  Five stars for the product that I've used forever.
These are the only paper targets I use at the range. No tape required as the entire thing is a huge sticker so you can just peel and paste it onto the target stand. I love that you can see where you hit as the impact point "explordes" a flourecant green. I dont have to use my spotting scope to see where I am hitting because of this. The smaller diamonds on the corners are 2" and the square grids are 1". Best target I have ever shot at.
These are the best of all I have tried. The multiple squares are ideal for range use because you can reuse without having to patch it up so often. Also you can use the corner squares to practice moving between shots The grid squares are 1" so it's easy to measure your groups. The bullet holes are easy to see for a good distance even with a .22 caliber bullet (maybe 25 yards or more if you have good eyesight). Perhaps the only downside compared to others is the overall size, but its never an issue for me.I've seen these used in History channel's Top Shot show, so pros like em.
When I started shooting at targets for more than a hundred yards to test the grouping of your rifle, this I found to be the best target to use.Depending on color of the foliage backdrop where you set up your target, time of day and level of dust and wind going around, some paper target hits get too hard to see from distance greater than 100 yards even with the spotting scope. These targets are awesome with the black on bright green. The hits are really clear but they don't bust out to wide to skew your grouping assessment.
I shoot rifles scoped and these targets give me a slew of aiming points.  The center target and the four outlying diamonds make five, and the four squares above, below, left and right make four more for a total of 9 discrete targets on a single sheet.  On the four squares I like to affix a little red dot from a shoot-n-c refill (you always have more of those than you use) to give me clear bullseyes on each of the additional four squares.The 1-inch grid gives you precise information, and the multiple aim points give great value.  Its my favorite target regardless of whether my scope is sighted in or not.
I thought I would try this item instead of a normal brass Hoppe's brush and here's my results.  The brush was very tight even with the Hoppe's fluid on it, it was very tough to push through a S&W m&p 15-22 bore. I planned on using this on a .223 chrome lined bore but will not attempt it because it was so tight. It did seem to clean fine and probably was a little quicker vs. the standard brass brush. Overall I wasn't too impressed and will stick with the normal and cheaper brass brushes from Hoppe's.
The tornado brush design is a major improvement over the traditional loop, and jag cleaning tips.  The flexing of the spiral loops against the lands & grooves with a patch over it does an excellent job of removing lead & powder residue.  The cleaning patch sits nicely over the end loop and in larger calibers (e.g., 45ACP, 12 Gauge shot shell) the loop will penetrate the cotton patch helping to secure it as you push the brush through the bore.  I use the brush in only one direction, pushing from the breech to the muzzle whenever possible.  I then unscrew the brush, remove the cleaning rod and repeat the process until the patch comes out clean.  For difficult to clean deposits, I use Lead Away cloth that I have cut to the diameter of the patches (Pro shot Flannel Patches) that I like to use.
This is a excellent hunting sling. I have used this on many hunts and on several different rifles ranging from .22lr-.30-06. It worked well on all of them. The only problem I have with the sling is that it will not work with certain bi-pods. I have a shooters ridge bi-pod on my Ruger American rifle and the sling attachment will not allow the legs of the bi-pod fully deploy. If you want a great sling to use for hunting and you are not going to use a bi-pod then this is the way to go, but if your rifle has a bi-pod then you might want to get a more traditional sling.
I've used many different slings over the years. Some of them prettier than this one, but none as practical. I love how well it grips your shoulder, no more slipping around as you're hiking. The plastic swivels are fantastic. I was at first skeptical of the durability of plastic swivels, but soon realized that they are well made and will not damage your stock or squeak like the metal ones sometimes can. This is the only one I'll buy in the future. I have  black one.
I bought this for a Remington 700 XCR Tactical with the Bell & Carlson green/black stock.  The green cammo sling color is identical to the stock color.  My stock comes with two mounting studs on the foregrip so I also have a Harris Bipod (3-9") mounted.  With the bipod mounted it doesn't give the sling much freedom of movement so I end up removing the bipod until I need it.  Like everyone else said, this sling doesn't slip.  Highly recommended!
These paper targets are the same ones used for police training and concealed carry qualification. The paper is a bit fragile so having a helper hold it in place while stapling it to the backing is helpful. I use 8 staples and that works in every windy situation I have encountered. When I am feeling thrifty I cut some black electricians tape into small squares to patch over the holes and get about three uses out of each target. That may be a false economy, since each target costs less than what two rounds of 9 mm or .40 cal ammo that I am shooting at it. There is a grid for recording the date and score. The targets come rolled up and are a little bulky to deal with when pulling one out. It helps to have a nice clean floor to roll them out then reroll what is left and return to the box they came in. So far I have been quite pleased with them.
These Champion Silhouette Targets are exactly what we wanted for use at the ranges where we shoot. Bringing these to the indoor range is a lot less expensive than buying them on-site and they are printed on fairly heavy paper so they hold up well at our outdoor range, even when there is a strong breeze.I like that these are large since it makes getting "on paper" much easier when sighting in and will occasionally attach8" Round Birchwood Casey Shoot - N - C Self - Adhesive Targetswhen using smaller calibers or at long distances.These are also very good value for the overall quality and quantity.Recommended!CFH
This allows you to hold the case in a drill, after de-capping, and spin the case against some steel wool instead of spending more money and buying a tumbler and media to clean the outside of the case. No chance of getting cleaning media trapped in the case when reloading and raising the pressure through the roof. It also allows you trim the case to the correct length, while that isn't needed so much in revolver cartridges like the 357 mag, it is needed in the automatics like the 9 mil and rifle cartridges.
I purchased a barrel "in the white" that needed to be blued to match the gun it was installed on.  I didn't have to deal with stripping an old finish that cut down on a few steps.  I simply degreased the barrel, and applied the bluing with a q-tip.  When I was done, I rinsed it off with water, then cleaned it with gun solvent.  I applied 2 coats in this manner.  It delivered a nice consistent bluing.  After the two coats I saturated it with gun oil and let it sit for a couple of days in case I missed any spots and rusting started back up.  With no issues I installed the barrel.  It still looks good, and was a simple process to apply.  I recommend this product.

This is a great cold gun blue. I received it within the time allotted, but when it arrived, I had no idea what it was. I have ordered several items, getting ready for hunting season, and several items are made by Safariland. When this bottle arrived, the supplier glued their own label across the bottle which covered the product information and the instructions. When I tried to remove their label to see if it was bluing or cleaner,  the original label tore off with added shipping label. I do not like chemicals on my gun shelf that are not properly labeled, for safety sake. I have compared the bottle with on line pictures and this is bluing, so I will relabel the bottle, but this should not of happened. I will order else where next time.
I have an old 20 guage thats worth more in memories than actual value.  I've had it since I was 13 and I am 43 now.  Last December I hunted when it was snowing outside and got the gun wet so after the rabbit hunt I wiped it down and put it back in the case where I did not touch it again until this August.  Imagine my surprise when I looked at this totally rusted gun! I searched Amazon and found Black Magic, read the reviews and decided I would give a try.  The rust came off easily with steel wool and after I put the bluing on it looks as good as new.  I put two coats on according to the directions and couldn't be happier with the results.  If you screwed up like I did and left your gun in a case instead of taking it out you might want to try this product.  Just my two cents.
Contains the basics to clean your gun(s).  The tools are certainly adequate and perform as intended.  If you go to the range a 2 - 4 times a month and do a thorough job cleaning and lubing, you will run through the supplied pads and cleaner fairly quick (but don't over use the cleaner / lubricant).  The brush is a bit awkward for my little S&W Bodyguard .380, but it is functional and Q-tips work well of course.  For my 38 revolver and 40 S&W it is just fine.
I think this is a great kit for the price. I originally ordered a cleaning kit of the berreta website. 10 days later they send me an email saying that the order has been cancelled because it was not in stock. That brought me to Amazon to order this kit and I am glad I did. It was cheaper than the other one I wanted to buy and I don't miss anything from the other one. I have not used to cleaner that comes with it because I prefer Hoppes 9 cleaner and Hoppes oil but a lot of people use the cleaner with good success. Just a personal preference for me. Everything else in the kit works great. I gave it a 4 instead of a 5 because the rod that it comes with does feel a little cheap. I do not think it will break but I wouldn't have minded it to be a little more sturdy. Still a great product for the money. My recomendation would be to buy it.
Pros:Small overall package that cleans lots of popular gunsWell made components and clear instructionsPull only design is quick and easyPull only design follows the philosophy that the barrel should only be cleaned in the direction of bullet travelCons:Brass brushes are stiff and may be more aggressive than something like aHoppe's Tornado Brush for .45 Caliber PistolsPull only design will not allow aggressive scrubbing that a rod based system mightThe all in one cleaner/lube included is not my favorite - I preferHoppe's M-Pro 7 Gun Cleaner - 8 Ounce Spray BottleOverall:This is a great product that I would recommend to anyone.  Most of my cons are preferences and minor differences.  I really like that it stows to a very small package that will take up minimal closet/tub/pack space.  This is really nice if you often are cleaning in the field.  Give it a try, you will not be disappointed.
I bought this kit for putting into a pack for with the intention of being able to clean multiple calibers. I used it today for the first time and clean an AR-15 (5.56), a 12-Gauge, a Marlin .22, and a .22 Sig Mosquito. This kit cleaned them all with ease. I got anywhere from 3-6 cleanings out of each patch without a problem depending on the severity of the "grime."
