I have seen these kits advertised for some time and I didn't know how good they might be or if it was all advertising hype.  I'm very happy with this product, I can just throw it in my range bag and go, everything I need to clean my firearm is in there, from brushes to patches.  I've used the bore snake in the past, and still use it, but this handy little kit really works well,  Only problem I've encountered is that the pieces are sometimes a bear to get back in the kit, but what else is new?  Everytime I take anything out of a package, I have problems getting it back together.  I've finally come to the realization, it's operator error!  I highly recommend the Otis cleaning system.
After hearing so many good things about Otis kits I dropped (the not unsubstantial) $40 on this kit.  While it's a good idea, I really don't think it lives up to the hype.  The bore cleaning procedure is effective, probably about as good as using a proper rod, brush and jag.  But that's about all you can do with this kit.  There is no way to clean any complex chamber- the short wire tool is next to useless in an AR chamber.  There is no toothbrush, only enough oil for one or two cleanings, and no room to put a good rag in the pouch.  After one use I've gone back to keeping a bore-snake, toothbrush, bottle of CLP and rag in my field kit and keeping a proper cleaning kit at home.The Otis kit is not worth the money, or the hype.
What a great idea. The patches can be used as many as six times each. It takes a little practice to get the hang of where to pinch the patch, but once you do it works great. Also: After you pinch the patch and pass it through the slot in the brass tip, DO NOT pull it to tight(just snug will do)or it will be VERY hard to remove and use again. The cable system is great for the mini 14 type rifles. this kit is great for trips to the range or on a hunting trip. Every thing you need is in this small package.I highly recommend.
While I normally use BoreSnakes for a one-and-done approach to cleaning my pistols, I picked up one of these Otis kits for more of a detail strip and clean. For the price, you really get a lot for your money in this kit. All the included components are really well made and will stand up to years of abuse. The only negative thing I have to say about the kit is that the pouch that holds everything wasn't sewn correctly and the zipper hangs up about 3/4 of the way around. In my case, I need to pull on the edge of the pouch and really yank the zipper to get it closed. Small price to pay for something so portable and complete however. Cleans everything from my AK to my .22 pistol.
The design is excellent for compactness and portability yet comprehensive in inclusion. Intuitively usable, though I did read all the instructions (which I recommend - they help with total understanding and were especially useful when I resolved a blockage issue in a rifle barrel). The many provided sizes of brushes and patch holders are marked with large indications of caliber - very helpful when making choice. Easy to use very quickly and I really like the concept - it makes sense, but also provides the ability to do a quick barrel- and exterior-cleaning more frequently as well as a more thorough cleaning with a total break-down of the firearm. I cleaned 3 rifles and 3 pistols consecutively the day I got it and was very pleased at how quickly I was done and even more so because it was a very thorough cleaning of all in much less time than usual.
I was very excited when I first started using this.  Eventually I ended up discovering that a &#34;one size fits all&#34; kit really wasn't what it was cracked up to be, even though there were multiple elements to the system that helped it have a chance at being so.  The parts are easy to use, but also easy to lose.  The bag has great zippers but doesn't zip up very easily, is bulky and cumbersome for what it is, and doesn't hold its parts very well.  This often lead to losing parts.  The brushes included also don't include some of the more popular calibers (namely the .223/5.56mm).  It's ok, but I think that just sticking with dedicated kits for particular firearms is going to be better.
This kit is decent and comes with the basics to clean most guns. However, it does not come with a .223/5.56 brush! Kinda silly since it claims to be 'tactical' yet does not support the AR caliber... I called Otis and they sent me a free one in the mail and threw in a mop as well! This also does not include a .22 limited breech brush. If you want to clean a standard ruger or any rimfire rifle you will need to buy that separately.I recommend breaking down and using the Otis patches, trying to cut your own is very frustrating. If you find them on sale you can get 1,000 of them for $48
Great little cleaning kit. I've slowly migrated to this kit for most of my cleaning. I still have some other nylon brushed that I use on a few of my firearms, but this kit gets heavy use. I like the different sized cleaning snakes and the way the patches work with the kit. If you are buying this kit though, make sure you get extra cleaning patches. Also, I would store the patches separately from the kit. I noticed some discoloration on patches that I have left in the kit (I assume from cleaner/oil I have used with the kit while cleaning.) I use different gun oil and solvent than included, but I like knowing I have a tube in the kit just in case I need it while I'm away from home.
I have 2 other cleaning kits at home.  I ordered this because the slotted tips are brass (not plastic) and the cleaning rods are flexible and roll up, making it very small to transport.  Having now used it, I found the quality to be great.  The included cleaner isn't my preferred solution (I like Ballistol), but that was an easy swap.  The slotted tips are brass, so they won't bend and break. It is important to read the instructions as the way they want you to use the included patches is different than what most people do with the standard slotted tips.  It includes brushes, obstruction removers, etc.  It's a great kit, I highly recommend it. I can use this from my 22lr pistol all the way up to my shotguns,
Good holster for the price. I have it attached to an NCstar crossdraw vest on the belt. Took a little work but it does accept a full 2" belt. The retention is good, and it locks in positively. No worries when running. It actually holds the pistol a lot closer to the body than I expected and I like it. The rivets are pretty good and I think they will hold up. It's not a high dollar holster so its not the most beautiful injection molding but it has a purpose and serves it well. Not made in America, so no 5th star but its a good product. I have a video review on the u-tube - seach ThatDudeSirraj if you want to see it in action.
This holster fits my gun perfectly and clicks in place.  The paddle fits well, the clip is strong, the materials are good, there is a surface inside the paddle that is grips comfortably against the body. The only draw back is that it has two bumps along the waistline that poked into my side.  You can either tuck in your shirt or smash the bumps down.  I got a vice grip and just squeezed the crap out of them - and now it fits perfectly. Other than that minor tweak - I am super happy.
This holster gets three stars for its three star price and the equal quality of the product.  It retains K-frame Smiths OK, L-frame is a better fit for retention.  The attachment of the paddle to the body of the holster is weak, it does flap a bit easier than I'd like.  I had no misconception of what the product was, I needed a cheap holster that would retain a hammerless (DAO) Smith 64 and this fits the bill.  I wear a 1.75&#34; belt and there is a bit of a fit issue - the paddle/holster junction is a bit narrow so I get a poor fit.  A 1.5&#34; belt works fine.  Also note that depending where the belt loop of your pants is located this might also effect how the holster rides.
I recently purchased this Fobus Double Mag holster.  I'm currently deployed and use this Mag holster do house 2 9mm double stack mags for my Beretta M9 (92FS).  I've never had problems with Fobus products and I was just as pleased with this one.  A feature I like is the material they place on the inner portion of the Holster.  It's rubber like, allowing the holster to better grip to the wearer.  Retention could be slightly bette, but I havn't had any problems with Mags falling out.  It is, afterall, a multi-use mag holster.
I have a Gen 4, Glock G21 (.45 ACP) and this magazine holster does a fantastic job holding two mags.  They actually "lock" in place and will not fall out. You can easily pull them from the holder but they won't accidentally fall out.  The paddle that tucks in your pants is very secure but not too difficult to put on or remove (i.e. you don't have to unbutton your pants to get in on like I do to put on or take off my Serpa CQC holster).  I purchased this primarily for range use because it is far too big to conceal without layers of clothes.  However if you can open carry or just headed to the range it's perfect.
I ordered this Fobus 9mm/.40 S&W; for use with my Glock 17 magazines.  It fits into place comfortably and securely.  I don't feel that it will ever slip.  It took some getting used to when bending over and the like, but otherwise it's magic.  You can do a handstand and the mags will never fall out of their slots, yet when you want to draw one, it slides out with ease.Fobus knows how to make holsters (gun or mag); get this one with the paddle for ease of donning (and doffing).  Fantastic item for the price!
I purchased this double magazine holder for CCW purposes.  For that purpose, it is an abject failure.  Simply put, it is too large and bulky.  It is very high quality; of that you cannot quarrel.  However, as can be seen in the photo, the construction is bulky by design.  There are rivets on the outside.  It makes it very hard to carry under a shirt nearly anywhere except right in your front waist area.  That, however, makes it impossible to crouch or bend down, and makes it entirely obvious that you are carrying something -- which defeats the purpose of CCW.  Unless you are walking into a gunfight, for which no concealment is necessary or warranted, I suggest a different product.
The mag pouch arrived very quickly. I am using it on both my G34 and G19 that use the double stack mags.  The mags fit perfectly with just the right tension to keep them secure but not enough that they don't come out when doing a mag change.  I was a bit apprehensive about a paddle type retainer on this pouch.  However, since I have given it a try and wear it on a daily basis the paddle system does very well.  It is getting more comfortable the longer I wear the unit.  Strong material, I don't expect any issues with the construction of the pouch.
There are more bad reviews on youtube than good ones for this Fobus holster, but for the price I took a chance.  I couldn't be more happy with this.  It's incredibly light and simple and it stays securely in position on my hip.  My glock 21sf snaps in snugly and doesn't come loose on it's own, but when you mean to draw it releases easily.  The only reason I didn't give it five stars is because I have an ambidextrous magazine release and if you hit it just right with a full magazine it can release it.  But it's nothing 30 seconds with a dremel won't fix.
This Forbus Paddle Holster is an excellent choice for the Glock 30. One of my customers asked me to research a holster solution for his needs and this is one of the two I selected for him (Gould & Goodrich B891-G30 Concealment Belt Slide Holster (Black) Fits Glock 30, 39;  S&W; CS40, S&W; CS9, Taurus PT140, Sig 239, S&W; M&P; 9, .40, .357 and .45).I like paddle holsters for their ease of putting on and taking off but generally personally prefer "Level 2" type holsters like,BLACKHAWK! Serpa CQC Carbon Fiber Black Holster (Matte Finish). My customer's needs are different than mine and this one was the style he wanted.This is a very well made holster that works as expected!Highly Recommended!CFH
I purchased the Fobus Holster on Sunday and received it on Thursday.  I was nervous about the holster because all I have heard is to buy Uncle Mike's Holsters at $60 to $80 bucks.  This Holster fits my .45 Glock 30sf PERFECTLY.  As long as you have a sweater on or something baggy its great.  Its a little big for a T-Shirt but hey, the Glock itself is a fat little gun.  This holster will be perfect for the range and the gun fits in it nicely.  I highly recommend this holster.
Fits my S&W 686 (6 shot) perfectly.  When snapped, it's nice that the thumb loop acts to prevent the hammer from being pulled back, making it an idea holster for both wear and travel.  The color doesn't really match what's in the picture, but it's not orange.  That's just an over-exaggeration.  Leather is a good quality and there are two slits in the back loop that allow the holster to fit on both a wide belt and a regular (everyday) belt.
Great holster where fast action is needed, I would recommend it to anyone needing this type of holster.Holds my Ruger GP-100 .357 Mag in place, needed to have the gun in the holster for a week, so it streatches out a little,I used some leather cleaner/conditioner on the holster, put gun in a plastic bag into the holster, when the resdue was cleanedand the gun inserted, that did the trick, it now easy to pull out.  Before this process, I had to hold the holster, thenpull the gun out.  I also wore it around the house, wife comments not given.......
This fits the Taurus Tracker 44 Magnum like it was made for it- like a glove.  It carries like a dream and is a top notch product.  I am a hard on reviews and products but this leather holster is of very high quality and is spot on for concealed under a jacket or open carry use.  This was a wise purchase and I have worn it / put it to use since I got it.  The &#34;hawg leg&#34; can be drawn without issues and a 4 inch barrel fits in it perfect without too much room or too little room in the holster.  They should call this the Taurus Tracker 44 Mag holster because you would swear it came made for this revolver.  Thank you Bianchi!!!  My &#34;Hawg Leg&#34; 44 fits perfectly in this holster and I could not ask for more.  The safety strap snaps fine without too much tension and without too little tension.  I would buy again and recommend to my friends to buy this for carry use.
This is a wonderful holster for my Ruger SP101.  It fits perfectly.  Like others have stated though, the thumb snap is difficult to work with the gun in the holster at first.  But once in and snappped, you leave it for a day or so and the leather forms to your gun and the snap begins to work fine.  After that, it's terrific.  The only thing I wish for it is an adjustable cant.  But I knew it didn't have one before I ordered so won't dock stars for that.
Really good quality holster for my Glock 26.  At first I didn't think it would fit (that's what she said) and be able to snap in but after using a little bit of strength it fit perfectly.  The leather is excellant quality.  Although having the snap does sacrifice draw time for security.  However the way it's made allow me to easily flip my thumb to undo the snap which is awesome.  Reholstering though is a bit of a struggle.  I only gave it 4 stars because my Crimson Trace Lasergrip hasn't arrived yet and I'm thinking the gun will not fit in this holster with the lasergrip installed.
I`m here to tell all of you that have never tried this stuff for finishing wood, use it. You won`t be sorry. Just take your time, put on 5 to 8 coats and rub lightly after each coat dries with fine steel wool and you1ll have the most beautiful and glossy finish you`ve ever seen! It works great on plain wood and stained wood. I just refinished a 30-30 that my girl got from her Dad years ago. It looks FANTASTIC! It arrived earlier than expected, was packaged well, and is one heck of a product! Whether your a journeyman or a begginer with wood, you can`t go wrong with Tru-oil. Just be patient and take your time and let it sit for 2 hours to dry in between coats, polish lightly with fine steel wool and you`ll get a lifetime of enjoyment out of WHATEVER you finished with it! I HIGHLY recommend Fuddlebucks. Also, thanks Amazon for making my life easier!
Tru-Oil is very easy to apply and produces excellent results. I use it on firearms stocks and other woodworking projects. I know the instructions say to apply with your fingertip, but I much prefer a using folded up piece of cheese cloth instead. Application with the cheesecloth is faster and lays on the product even. Store the cloth in a plastic bag until you are ready for the next coat. For an heirloom quality finish, spend some time getting the pores and grain filled by following the instructions for that procedure from Birchwood Casey. The end result is a glossy, nearly flawless finish. You can knock down the gloss with a light rub down with 0000 steel wool.
This gun stock finish is just about the simplest applying finish I've found.  The instructions provide various options for application, but I have found that rubbing on with a finger provides the best control and results.  Proper attention to wood preparation prior to application pays big dividends.  Waiting 12 hours between coats is a must.  If blemishes have occurred, light rubbing with 0000 steel wool followed by a rub down with an alcohol dampened cloth prior to another coat can result in a near mirror finish.  Have finished six different stocks and won't use anything other finish product.
I have used Tru-Oil on about 15 different projects (all firearm related).I have used this mostly over min-wax stains as a sealer.Use light coats it goes a long way.  I let my coats dry 24hrs between applications and use a 0000 steel wool lightly between coats.So far all the projects I have done with Tru-Oil over the years have held up great.  It isn't too hard to strip if you want to take it off (mineral spirits) and you can always touch up by knocking the top coat down with some steel wool and applying new coats.
Bought this after getting beat in a woodworking competition where a decorated gunstock beat out one of my guitars using Tru-oil. Bought a 20 oz. bottle and found it incredibly easy to layer up, dries comparatively fast, and is much harder than lacquer. Found bulk disposable non-linting application towels for application and basically put my spray equipment away for guitars.  Just great stuff, and it takes very little to put on a coat. Takes 7-8 coats to get glassy. Polishes well with clear coat swirl polish. Just outstanding stuff.
This is as pictured.  This holster is excellent for UNconcealed carry such as hunting.  I can't see it being concealed with a full size firearm, like my Ruger.  It fits the firearm well, but it you push the firearm into holster, it has kicked out of safety while walking.  Hence the 4 stars.  I have tried different angles, but always seems to fit same.  Maybe other firearms, with a different safety system, have no problem.  Great seller,great price.
Never shot trap or skeet before and wanted to learn without the hassle or embarrasment of joining the league.  That's not to say anything wrong with that, just going to get some basic skills down (like sighting, leading a target, etc.) before I let the pros school me.  So this seemed like the right piece of equiptment.  Boy was it.  So much fun.  Relatively easy to assemble (if you're mechanical otherwise give yourself an hour or so) and instructions moderately clear.  At first I couldn't hit 5 of 10, but very soon the basic skills just came natural.  At the end of 100 rds, I was doing almost 9 or every 10 clays.  SO MUCH FUN.  Couple more training sessions and I'll be ready to head to the league for some pointers and comradery.  I think if the One-Step broke tomorrow it would have been worth the price of entry into this sport.
Ten minutes to assemble and this is the first time I've put one together. The instructions are fine, if you actually read them, and don't try to re-engineer the product or make it sound more challenging then it is. Yes, the pictures on the box can get you there also as the small parts are already assembled, which leaves three larger assemblies to bolt together. The trap is sturdy, the welds are excellent, as is the paint and finish, and it is light enough to toss in the back of an SUV or car trunk.Going with the recommendations included with the instructions for spring tension and trigger setting, placing clays as the instructions suggested, caused the trap to throw clay pigeons exactly as the instructions predicted.
This thing is great! Going out shooting is hard sometimes because I have to find a buddy to pull clays for me. Not with this thing! I can load my gun and the trap and simply stand on it to pull and fire my gun with ease. I like that it has 4 adjustable height settings. They're all fun and the highest and lowest are the hardest, but it's nice to switch things up. It doesn't really dig itself out of the ground like the traps that require I string to be pulled either. Very sturdy. Easily assembled. 2 clays don't fly great on it, but for singles it's awesome.
I just got into the sport of trap shooting and I got this based on the solid reviews this device got compared to others offered on Amazon.  Seems to be pretty solid, very easy to use, and was at a very good price when I got it (~$90).  Only had it for a week which only included one outing so I can't really judge the durability.  But I wrote this review to mention one thing.  The instructions are poor.  Took me under two hours (granted I only had one wrench and it needed two, I had to improvise) and the second half of the directions were pretty much useless but looking at the picture on the box was able to get me through the last half.  With better instructions and the proper tools, I should have finished it tops 30 minutes.  So I will just knock off one star due to the manual.  For those who want to know before buying, it is made in China.
I have been needing to purchase a thrower for practice for upcoming duck season. I thoroughly researched them off the internet and read numerous reviews. I almost ordered one from cabelas, but  decided not to spend the $350.00 plus for an automatic thrower. I like how this one requires minimal work to load and throw your clays. I went through 2 boxes so far and none have broke while being thrown and also throw clays very well. No gripes from me and I saved a few hundred bucks. This should also last longer since I don't have to worry about supplying a battery, nor does is have wires that can corrode and require maintenance. This is a SOLID INVESTMENT. Highly recommend. This thrower also has some of the highest ratings you will find..A+
Nice case for the money.  I bought it to store my Rossi rifle.  The quality of the external material is very nice.  It feels good in the hand.  The stitching is very neat.  As for the interior material, it is smooth and the rifle does not leave an impression in it like some cases.  I liked the tin can graphic on the case since I plink with rifles.  The hanging loop on the small end is attached to the case with a rivet, not with stitching. I like that extra security that the rivet brings.  This case is very reasonably priced.  I have several good Allen cases.  I think this is the best of the lot.  Would be nice if different colors were available for this model, so if I had another I could tell which rifle is in each case.
Granted, these are nylon straps with elastic holders for 20 rounds, but a leather version of this would be upwards of $60.  So for $10 to get the same thing is a pretty good deal.  You can adjust to fit, then cut off extra with a pair of sissors.  My first belt, I took a lighter to the end when I was done to melt a little at the end of the strap to keep it together.  The second one I bought for a shotgun, I cut down, folded the end and stitched, the 3rd one I just cut.  ALL 3 have held up just fine.  Easy to use, easy to load and unload, great belt!
This is everything I was hoping for. It is sturdy and was absolutely easy to insert all 25 shells. I did find the easiest way to do it was insert every other slot and then go back and do the rest. The shells are held tight as a bug and no ammount of shaking seems to make them want to slide out. This is a guilty pleasure purchase for sure. I plan to use this as a bandolier not as an actual belt. I have tac holsters on my waist so no room for it to be used that way. Now I am ready for the zombie apocolypse, or the occupy people. LOL
I really like this shell belt.  It looks really cool when you throw it on and the fact that you can have 25 additional rounds around your shoulder or waist when you are in the field shooting clays makes this an awesome accessory.  Not the easiest to load but just like one of the other reviews pointed out it is easier to load every other round. I love the adjustability and snap on fastener which makes taking the belt off and putting it on much easier if it is around your waist.Great addition to add and also for the price it's a steal.
The rounds fit snug I have everything this baby from "00" Buckshot to birdshot. I am preparing a piece at a time for my "bugout" bag. and this is a neccessity. My bag contains an SOG axe, SOG survival knife, fire starting gear, SAS survival handbook, assorted batteries, poncho liner, thermal top, favorite t shirt, this belt, good pair of boots, .357 mag and plenty of rounds, good Mossberg shot gun, and and M-1 Garand for that long range shooting and knock down power. The bag it is all contained in besides the guns is a Spec-Ops brand bag which is a good strong bag with good zippers.
Four stars because 12 gauge shells must be vigorously wrestled into the belt with great effort. This belt really hits the mark for 20g shells. I have had issues with other belts for the 20g, but his one is perfect for this. It has less than stout buckles, but they work fine for me. I use one each for my 12 and 20 and would purchase them again. I have yet to lose a 12 gauge shell with this belt even after chasing quail in tall sage and through thick brush. It has held up through one season of vigorous hunting and I think will last for several more before becoming too loose like all the others I have used. It is worth the price considering none last me more than a few years.
Exactly what I needed, a belt that holds rounds for my shotgun and doesn't poke or prod me in uncomfortable places. It holds more than enough rounds for a belt piece and adjusts on the sides nicely, but what belt doesn't? The side adjust cinch is tight and doesn't stretch or come undone, however this may become less sturdy as time goes by but we'll see. Not a lot of bells and whistles, which I like. Straight to the point, exactly what I needed for the coming apocalypse ;) good hunting.
This belt is built really solid. The material is thick, the buckle is heavy duty and the shell holders are high quality elastic. About the only issue I have is that it is fairly difficult to insert the shells. A tip is to do every other one first and then fill in the blanks. I am assuming the elastic may relax a bit after a while. I am storing the belt with all 25 shells laoded in it and hoping that this may make the elastic relax a bit. The price can't be beat and the shipping was reasonable. I will post a picture of both sides of my belt fully loaded.
As with everything else I've found in the world of shotguns, this 20/12 ga. accessory is better suited for a 20 gauge, but will work alright for a 12. Reason being, the loops for the shells are tight enough to be inconvenient on the larger 12 gauge shells.The buckle is strong and secure, and the belt works just fine, otherwise. I would rather pay a little more and have the choice between the two sizes, but this item would work okay for hunting, as there's not really a rush to reload. It's not a great tactical accessory.
I wanted something to carry a little more shells than my sling did. This is perfect.Not to be paranoid but I wanted to have a good amount of shells ready and quick to deploy on the go. Didn't want to get a chest rig or anything too elaborate so this was the best option.I live in an urban area and fear that if there was some sort of natural disaster (we're overdue for a big quake here in CA) that panic might ensue. Stitching seems to be good quality, elastic nice and tight to hold shells so they won't fall out even after some wear(sorta difficult to put shells in first few times, but definitely a trade off I don't mind. I really like this belt.  I purchased it to hold 410 shells and they fit beautifully.  In also holds 20 gauge shell nicely as well.  I havent used it yet on 12 gauge, however I think they would be a very tight fit.  The belt is long, but can be ajusted to fit most any waste, however there is an excess of webbing strap that hangs when worn aroung the waste.  This may be so you can use it as a bandolier as well.  The side release webbing clip is of good quality and very large.  This piece alone is worth a few bucks seperately. THE ALLEN COMPANY SHOTGUN SHELL BELT IS BUILT VERY STRONG. THE INDIVIDUAL SHOTGUN SHELL HOLDERS ARE VERY TIGHT BUT I JUST RUN MY FINGERS IN EACH HOLE AND STRETCH IT OUT. (GIGGITY).  LIKE MOST REVIEWERS SAID THE BELT IS SUPER LONG SO WHEN YOU ADJUST IT TO SIZE THERE WILL BE LOTS OF EXCESS MATERIAL. BUT YOU CAN CUT IT AND BURN THE EDGE. WHAT I DID WITH MY EXCESS MATERIAL WAS I FOLDED IT UP AND RUBBER BAND TO THE MAIN BELT. I ALSO HAVE A M-4 CARBINE AND I HAVE CLIP HOLDER THAT I RAN IT THROUGH THE BELT AND OVER THE FOLDER PART. SO ALL IS GOOD. CANT WAIT TO TAKE THIS SUCKER OUT TO THE DESERT AND TRY THIS OUT.
I ordered this belt to carry extra shells for my 20 gauge and the shells fit perfectly, but when I put 12 gauge in the slots it stretches the elastic to the max so be careful.  The belt itself is made of good quality for the price and can allow for a sidearm holster to clip onto either side if you're in the field.  The only real flaw is that there is a lot of extra belt hanging off after tightening it so that seems to get in the way and should have some sort of loop to put it through.
I use this belt to hold 12ga shells. Excellent for that purpose and more.The length of the belt is so generous that I double the belt as a cheaper alternative to the bandolier also sold here on Amazon that is almost 3x the price of this belt.Ergonomically speaking, this belt will function fine as a bandolier. You can place the belt across your shoulder so that you have access to ALL 25 shells in front of you. With the "true" bandolier, half those shells will be awkward to reach for anyways.I only gave it 4 stars because the quality of the belt could be better by using a more durable material like canvas for the belt. But for the low price of this belt, I really shouldn't be complaining.4-stars for this belt as I'm actually really happy with my purchase.
This belt is very adjustable in terms of waist measurement. The shells only go about half way around the belt and the belt clips shut. Distributing the weight of the shells around your waist makes them feel like nothing compared to carrying them in an ammo bag/box. I've tried wearing this belt over my regular pants belt and because it's adjustable it works fine. Also, can be worn comfortably with the bandolier that holds shells or a backpack. The elastic that holds the individual shells to the belt is very strong and you can shake the belt upside down and the shells will stay put. The clip that fastens the belt is very sturdy. All in all- seems like very sturdy construction.
I received this and it is a bit lighter weight than I imagined it would be. The belt material is soft to the touch and very flexible, not stiff. Shell loops are elastic and only single stitched so I wonder at long term durability. Buckle is of good size and weight and looks like it should work well. Size would fit someone from a small waist to very large. I am a 36 + size waist and I had plenty of room plus or minus that for adjustment. The width of the belt is less than the length of the shells. On the plus side is that it with the light weight construction comes light weight. It can only weigh a few ounces so shouldn't add much weight over the weight of the shells.The spacing on the loops of elastic are even and worked well for 12 ga shells. They were very tight but all 25 fit in the belt. I will update this over time with usage.
A solid, wide-web belt with a plastic quick release buckle. There's ample length for ample waists, and the 25 shotshell loops do not take up the whole belt, so there's room for accessories, if you choose. I wear about a 34&#34;, and I can fit two magazine and one pistol holster comfortably alongside the shotshells. Construction quality is good. 12 ga shells are held very snugly. They are readily removed from a full belt; an empty one is pretty lightweight and requires just a bit more effort to get those last 2-6 shells out.
This shell belt is one good belt. holds the shells in place they are not coming out. i had no problems putting in the 25 shells was pretty easy. The belt is a strong stiff nylon belt. The only minor thing which is minor is the slack left over if your an average size guy 38inch waist or smaller. either cut the slack or like i did zip tied the slack. I use it for when i do outside shooting i have extra shells on me and i don't have to walk back to the table.
I use these to keep multiple shotgun shells ready for just in case.  It works best if you stagger the shells with primers facing up and down.  It would have been better if it was a little shorter and had the shell holders go further around it.  But it is a good buy for what it is.  You can fill these and then store them in an ammo can so that they are ready and protected.I use Amazon for most of my purchases and update my reviews if anything changes with the products. I do this so other Amazon users can get a real feel for the life of the product. You can look at my review which will be close to my purchase date and tell how the product is doing as time passes.  I am not associated with any company and all opinions are my very own.
I'm not sure why I thought this was a sling when i purchased it but I ended up keeping it anyway. I love the belt, I use it for 12 gage ammo and its fits very nice. It can be a bit time consuming putting shell per shell in the belt. I did actually have ONE issue, the buckle in the front would clip together but gave me such a hard time trying to take it off. Sometimes it would be easy to remove the belt and other times it would be difficult. I'm a 32' at waist and i still have quite a bit of the belt left over after i put it on nice and tight. I do recommend, it feels like good material. I don't have any other issues.
For the money or even if you want to spend more money.You can't beat this belt for serveing it's purpose.Glad I read the reviews before buying it though.It will hold 25 12 gauge shells very snugly.Do what the guy says in his reveiw.Insert in every other loop and then fill in the empty loops.Also it can serve as a pistol belt at the same time.Just make sure before you load it to turn it so the long empty part is on the side you want to wear pistol on.
So, while this isn't as high quality as the blackhawk variant or perhaps some others, it does exactly what it's intended to do and does it well. I don't understand all these people talking about how it's hard to get the shells in. You just start them on the side where the webbing extends past the loops, and rock them in. It takes about 2 minutes to load up the whole thing with 12G shells, and it's no problem.The elastic also appears to be holding up well, despite the fact that I've kept it loaded for several months now - it does not seem to be fatiguing. In general, I'd say that although it's not the highest quality piece you can get, it's a great value for the money and functions well.
I was looking for a range belt to hold .45 long colts. I was initially thinking about a leather cartridge belt, but the price of many of them drove me away. When I found this product I figured it was cheap enough to give it a shot so I did. I'm pretty pleased with the belt. It may not have the cowboy look of a leather cartridge belt but it works just as well not only a holding cartridges. I can slip on a holster for my 1858 cartridge conversion Remington, leather cylinder pouches and one bullet pouch and still keep it fast to my hip. I weighted it with everything on it including the gun and it weighed about 10 pounds. My only complaint with the design is that the "slack" left after you tighten it to your waist just flaps around and I had to tuck it into my holster so it didn't look like I was walking around with a bathrobe on. I sew on a small loop of fabric to use as a belt loop.
More than long enough to go around my above average waist size.  Well made.  I didn't buy it for the cartridge holders.  I use it to attach other shooting items to it - a pellet pouch, magazine pouches, and a .380 gun holster.  Works great.  I saw some reviews about the extra length being a problem.  What I did was use a paper clamp - the kind that is used to keep a rather thick (1/2 to 1 inch) stack of paper together.  Just attach it to the belt and then flip the handles down so it is smooth.  Dollar Store has them for 6 for a $1.00.
Got this belt to carry ammo for my Circuit Judge (.45 long colt and 410 shotshell). Works great for both. Also plenty of room to carry my pistol holster on one side and an ammo pouch on the other side for misc. My only complaint is that while it will adjust to almost any size with plenty of extra belt for larger sizes or for going over a heavy coat, there is nothing to keep the loose end of the extra belt length from just hanging and flopping around. They should have added a sliding loop of some kind to the end of the belt to keep it in place. Maybe I'll make something myself. But otherwise, very rugged and well worth the money.
I use this to carry my wife's grandfather's 16 gauge side by side, which has no swivels.  It does work just fine to slip on the stock and barrels, and make my way through the woods for turkey hunting.  I can see the complaints about strap position...they are valid.  However, for the price, I really don't notice it that much.  On a scale of 1 to 10, 10 being most annoying, strap position is a 2 or 3.  If you have a thin or sensitive shoulder, I could see it being a pain.The nice part is that it does carry the gun low enough that you are not hanging on every branch and &#34;waitaminute&#34; vine you go past.  Once you find your spot, you can slip it off the gun and get it out of the way.  Durability seems reasonable - I will use it until it dies and buy another.
For the price, I would expect this to be a bit more strong like Blackhawk merchandise. This is a great dual mag holder, the mags go in easy, and hold great, while allowing an easy but restrained pull out....no jokes on that guys....But my problem is how flimsy the area at the top of the belt line is. I literally feel like I'm going to break it, or bend it beyond repair when I put it on my hip.I doubt it would, but for $40+ there should be no doubt I bought a good mag holder. Better plastic my friends, get on it.
For just a few more dollars (totally worth it) you can have this same product shipped from a location closer than Israel.Although I've already ordered this product (a while ago) and am still waiting for it to arrive, I am familiar with this product.I used this during a pistol class and it worked like a charm.  It helps to have one of these at your hip for the simple, common-sense reason of having easy access to more mags at the firing line.The three stars are not geared towards the product itself.  The three star review represents the very, very long wait time.Be safe, people!
I ordered the 40in. (sm) GunMate Deluxe Rifle case for a Ruger 10/22 carbine.It was a PERFECT fit for the 10/22 with a 3-9X40 scope. My scope is mounted with UTG medium height quick disconnect rings.When I say perfect fit I mean that if my scope rings were higher or a had a hi rise picatinny rail it would have not fit.Yes it is a &#34;lockable&#34; case keeping in mind that it is vinyl and rather easily opened with a razor blade.Zipper appears adequate and strong enough along with plenty of padding without being bulky.
Pretty much all the other reviews are spot on with what you will find. They are cotton cloth patches that will sometimes leave threads. There are a lot of them in the package and the price is right for them. The only reason I didn't give them 5 stars is that I ordered .22 cal patches and they were just a hair big. They fit over the jag, but draped over the shank of the jag and onto the shaft of the Tipton carbon fiber cleaning rodTipton Deluxe Carbon Fiber Cleaning Rod with 22 to 26 Caliber and 8 x 32 Female Threadthat I bought at the same time.Pros:cotton clothcleangood pricegood quantityabsorbantMade from Southern Belle's Bloomers!Cons:The .22 cal was just a hair too bigThey will sometimes leave a stray threadThey are plain white. I was expecting some of them to have hearts or flowers on them since they are recycled bloomers.
Good deal on cotton patches which seem to clean better than the thin paper type.  However, I had trouble with it fitting through my Remington R700 in .308 caliber.  I had to fold to triangle shape and cut 1/4" off of each patch before running through.  No problems through 7.62x39 and 7.62x54 barrels though.  Not sure why that was the issue, since they are all .30 caliber.  I'm guessing it is the difference between my cleaning rods as I use different attachments for all 3.  However, would purchase again.
Product says the Pro's love this stuff but with the little cotton fibers coming loose all the time, (remember this stuff is made from cut up underwear) and leaving tiny little cotton pieces all over the floor, inside and outside all over my guns ain't a good thing to me.Maybe they can be used for something but I don't recommend using as gun patches especially when used when used with cleaning fluid or oil as the fluid just makes it order to pick up all those little almost microscopic pieces of cotton.
These patches absorb solvent and oil well.  I noticed I have to use one or two fewer patches, to effectively clean a barrel, than the less-absorbent patches I was previously using.  The one thing to be aware of, you do have to check each patch for loose strings at the edges.  As long as I pull any obvious loose strands, I haven't once left any behind in the barrel.  They work well, and are a good value.  I'm glad a fellow firearms enthusiast recommended them to me.  They also make good firestarters, for a field kit, if you char a small stack of them.
These are the same patches my unit supply command issues us to clean our weapons for range use/inspection/missions. Yes, they leave little strings here and there, but cleaning up after yourself and doing a final wipe-through inside your barrel is not something to cry about...These patches are weaved, which allows for better removal of carbon and other buildup than that of mops or non-weaved cotton patches. And because it is weaved, i've noticed that it also has more absorbancy than that of other patches.I give 5-stars for the product itself, and a thumbs-down for the price. I think a great bargain price would be closer to $15 for .223 patches instead of $18+shipping... But that's just my .02 cents.
The holster was very comfortable to wear and fit the gun nicely.  There is no issue with the gun falling out at all. The gun was very hard to unholster. There is a proper way to remove, and practice is needed to learn how to use the holster.  Using your other hand to hold the holster helped.  It is designed like this to keep anyone else from upholstering your weapon.  Only straight up &#34;snappy&#34; pulling of the gun will get it out.  Very nice holster if you can learn the proper technique.  I would have kept the holster, but I could not get the hang of it.

They are so hard to pop on and off it takes considerable effort and contortion to mount it on your belt.Update: After many iterations of putting it on and taking it off it has loosened up enough that I'd bump the star rating from 3 to 4. The tension screw has a tendancy to back out over time but is easy to tighten back up. I guess some locktite would fix it.

A tip for you friends:  pay 5.00 for a bale of straw, spray paint circles on the straw bale ofyour choice of colors, then you'll have a quality target that will last all summer.  In the winter cover it with a large plasticleaf bag, and put it in the shed for next summer.  Take heed to my message to you, I give you true and factual info. Thisis a fact, it is a s*** item.....

I scanned the size chart from the package and uploaded it.  Maybe this will help others.  It's a good quality uniform.  It's great for the price. This is a very basic sling; just some nylon straps and a standard pad. That's a compliment, not a criticism; fancy slings are good for some things, but for a normal hunting rifle this is ideal. Gel pads have too much bounce when I'm walking, and too much give to steady offhand aim. I don't need non-skid backing or elastic loops to hold ammunition. For what I want, this is well-made and economical.By the way, this sling does NOT include swivels. If you don't have spares, you should consider buying one that does include them, because if you buy them separately that can add $10-$15 to the total price of the sling. There are Allen slings on Amazon that have swivels installed for just a few dollars more than this one. This is truly the no-frills model; what you see is what you get.
The rubber knife is a rubber knife... the only bad part is that the &#34;silver&#34; rubs off really easily... an hour after taking the knife out of the packaging I saw that the knife had rubbed a bunch of silver paint on my pant leg; it wasn't a big deal, but now the fake knife looks like a black rubber knife instead of a fake knife... oh well, it was cheap and fun.  maybe a can of spray paint will bring back the &#34;silver look&#34;
I used this knife for a film and looked fine on camera, but while using it in a fighting scene, the blade part ripped off.We are unsure if it was just that one unit, or if its not that durable. It is made out of rubber and feels like a really good quality rubber.We purchased 2 more just in case, and they did not break.One con if you use it for a movie, the blade part often bends and is hard to make it strait.Overall, whether you use it for combat training, film or stage, you will enjoy this product.
Heavier and more rigid than the tanto version but has the benefit of an integral hand guard. The paint cracks and peels quickly so it gets ugly fast. Other then that it's well made and lasts under heavy use. I've had a half dozen of these for training classes and they've held up perfectly for almost five years now. They bend but don't break, hit hard enough to tell you've been struck, but don't leave any lasting injury though they do have a tendency to leave welts with heavy impact where the lighter tanto-style knives do not. I strongly suggest avoiding head shots or wear appropriate protection. Great value-priced training tool.
I bought these based on the reviews and I am very pleased with their performance.  I originally bought PD-M424 but returned them for these when I read more reviews.  The resin cages around the pedals make it very easy to keep your foot on the pedal from a stop while locking in your cleat.  It also allows you to unclip and still have room for your foot on the pedal.  I have not tried using these without cleated shoes but I think it would work for short rides.Durability not an issue so far but I'm not a racer and don't get very wild when I ride.
I've been using these pedals for four years, and they've been consistently great. They're incredibly easy to clip into, and flip into proper position almost instantly. Clipping out is totally natural. Most importantly, if you're in tight traffic (middle lane of 6th Avenue in midtown Manhattan at rush hour, for example), and need to clip out for an instant because of some hazard ahead, it's possible to maintain total control using the flat of the pedal until you have the space/speed/security to clip back in. I find the M647s to be totally practical whether I'm pulling a heavy trailer or traveling light. I've recommended the pedals to many friends.They're comfortable with street shoes too.
It is silky smooth. Click in and click out easily. On sketchy section, you could un-clip for quick bailout  and still have a platform to stand on or pedal (but i do not recommend that). Pedal is not level. You will feel the clip in the middle with sneakers. Also, you could also pedal on uphill restart without immediately click in. Not for beginner. Beginner should use flat pedal to learn the cycling skill. Learning clip and unclip with other skills at the same time is too much too ask. I found out the hard way. You get nervous click-in on sketchy sections. You tighten up naturally. You will crash the section  you could have clear otherwise.Otherwise, it is sweet.

Sensei likes the weight of it for that reason and that it will also build some strength and control.  My son loves that it has a cool design. I was impress how quickly this came and was very happy with the staff they sent me (ordered on Mon and received by Friday).  It is not a finished staff or pole, there are slight bumps where branches were coming off the sapling (These can be sanded off quite easily), but it is straight...as straight as something natural can be.  The length was great, but I cut it down to use as a hiking stick/spear shaft for the Cold Steel Bushman blade. I bought two of these based on a review that said they were inconsistent.  The review was spot-on, and I bought them, even knowing I would have a lot of work to do.  I have been able to straighten them somewhat by wetting and steaming, and have sanded one to get rid of the knot bumps, and, for the work, they are usable, if not "performance grade."I would take the chance again, since for the martial arts I practice (Tai Chi Chuan), spear forms are a high-level exercise.  The spears have a heavier point, and these would otherwise be ideal, if they were something thicker.  I suppose it counts on how many are in the "batch" received from China, and when one buys.  I'm still hoping I can get them worked out.
INITIAL REVIEW UPON PURCHASING:I purchased this hand pump for inflating my bike tires.  I am only an occasional biker, so I use it every month or two.  Thus far, I have been very pleased with its performance.  It's easy to pump and makes quick work of my bike tires.  Those interested in getting perfectly optimized pressure will need a separate pressure gauge, as one is not included with this pump.TWO MONTH UPDATE:I've owned the bike pump for two months and used it exactly twice. Yesterday, when I attempted to pump up my tires, the entire thing broke in two.  I guess inexpensive really does mean cheap in this case.  I'll be searching for a better quality pump in the future.
Sorry, old SNL skit with Hanz and Franz. [...] But this air pump gets me as excited as a LITTLE... GIRL... (Sorry again).Seriously, a very good pump that I have been using for a while to pump up a slowly leaking car tire, which takes a LOT of pumping to fill, so you know it's durable.  On suggestion is to tie up the bottom of the hose so that there is not a lot of motion where the rubber meets the steel.  I've found in other pumps that that is always where the failure eventually happens.Great value.

When i bought this shoe, what i had in mind were the following:-Flexible: The thin sole made it very flexible.-affordability: It costed me only around 20 bucks so it is very affordable.-no heel: there wasn't much of a heel-space for toes: sadly this is were this shoe and many others fail to measure up, the toe box is pretty tapered. These martial arts shoes are fantastic for many reasons. For one, they have helped to straighten my back ... doctors say that there is nothing better for relieving stress on your back than walking barefoot. Also, the soles on these shoes are so thin that they are the next best thing to walking barefoot. I am 50 years old, and I have suffered from fallen arches, over-pronating ankles, and plantar faciitis for 31 years. Strengthening my arches and ankles by wearing these martial arts shoes has helped to correct my foot issues. After two months of wearing these shoes, my arches and ankles have become so strong that I have even thrown away my orthotics and arch supports. I can now walk barefoot all day long with no pain. I even run barefoot too!
I do yoga in my garage workout area. I bought these shoes to do yoga in the garage in the winter so that my feet would not freeze. These shoes work great for that. They are very flexible and are the next best thing to bare feet. The shoes are canvas with rubber soles and a rubber toe cap that extends about three inches down each side of the shoe. This rubber toe cap works great to  protect the shoe when holding poses like &#34;upward dog&#34; when the tops of my feet are supporting the weight of my legs. They are not perfect. The build quality is good but not great in terms of appearance, but they seem durable. You can't beat them for the price. You should buy a pair. I wear a size 12 running shoe. I ordered these in a size 45 and they fit fine.
These shoes are not just hype, they are everything te say and then a lot more. They look great, fell great and are buit to last, I usualy go through a pair of shoes every 6 months (give or take) praticing capoeira, name brand shoes, generic shoes, I go through the soles, rip open the front pont where your toes are,  none have withstood as much as these. They are going on a year now and they look like they can last another year,  easy. Highly recomend them, the sole is padded for great comfort and performance.

They are lightweight and fun, really cool for flipping and trampoline follies (literally in my case).  They don't real have the right structure for suspension trainers (I'm a TRX Qualified Trainer), I'd use minimals for something like that.I don't know wushu from mushu, but they are comfortable and fun to wear.

The rubber on the bottom hasn't been worn out yet, and this review is coming from an amateur wushu athlete who practices on concrete (and likes to drag her feet when she walks). We have a 22 year old son who loves being barefoot, but that's not always practical due to weather. He really likes the lightness and comfortableness of these shoes for his general purpose wear (not martial arts). We buy about one new pair each year. His use is probably about 6 months of HEAVY walking (3-6 miles per day). These aren't designed for this, but they hold up pretty well. He basically just wears through the soles.So, these can be used for more that just martial arts. As comfortable and light footware, they work well.
I wear these shoes for pretty much everything but running.  As other reviewers have mentioned, these are extremely comfortable with a wide base to provide plenty of traction and grip.  The rubber soles and canvass uppers make them very flexible while still providing some support.  These shoes are great for martial arts as well as normal everyday use.  I often just wear them around the house because they are so comfortable.  They do tend to show sweat stains very easily, but it's understandable being that they're made from white canvass.
The only issue one might find with these is, as another reviewer mentioned, the warning regarding carcinogenic ingredients.  My guess is these probably have some amount of lead in them, under the paint.  I used to live in CA and the same warning was put on wine bottles for the foil used to enclose the ends.  I figure with these weights I'm not going to be touching them too often and I'll just wash my hands after each use.Otherwise, these are well made, clean and exactly what I wanted.  I'd order them again.
- Using these 1&#34; weight plates with the 1&#34; EZ bar from the same company.- It's a cost effective solution, the weights feel true to weight or close enough that I didn't feel the need to weight them on a scale or anything.- Issue I had is they marked the floor very easily. I placed the EZ bar down with the weight on it on a basement floor with flooring over it, and it marked the floor with paint from the weight plate. I wasn't pleased with this. Therefore I have the weights on a yoga mat to prevent this issue. It's not a deal breaker because you can get yourself up with an EZ bar set that doesn't break the bank, but just be aware of that little issue.- Amazon Prime quick delivery and the pricing makes it easy to add more weight plates when needed.
I moved into a place that had a missing lateral sewer cover in the garage. The city water/sewer department indicated it wasn't their responsibility because it was on the condo HOA grounds and don't sell to the public. The HOA said it was the homeowner's responsibility since it's located in the garage floor. It seemed getting an iron cover was impossible. Behold I thought to find a barbell weight plate that would hopefully be as close in diameter to the hole opening as possible. I stacked two of these plates on top of each other and the open is now perfectly covered and it's level with the pavement now too.
These are weights so not much to say about them or what you're supposed to do with them.  They are high quality metal plates so should last a lifetime easily.  Anyway, the idea here is to buy them to save some money.  The prices fluctuate a lot so you need to pay attention and be patient.  It's really nice having these shipped to your door because it saves a lot of time and these can of course get heavy, being a bit awkward to carry with you.
I used this to start a fire in the rain with tinder and fuel tabs.  I was able to light my tinder in 2 strikes with this the very first time I used it.  I'm not 100% sure if the credit belongs to the tinder, the starter, or both but that's hard to beat.  Using the dull back side of my knife, I was able to easily create and impressive amount of sparks with each strike.  I plan to test it again soon and see how it fares, but it's initial performance blew me away.  I have no choice but to give it a 5 out of 5.
I purchased several of these repackaged at WalMart (though they still say Coghlan on the brick) as well as one at Amazon. Rather than rehash what the other reviewers have said (which is essentially accurate) I'll just say it works if you do what you are supposed to do. I keep one of these in each of my various packs (3-day bag, Camelbak HAWG, Camelbak Ambush) as you never know when you might need a fire. Yes, your handy lighter might work, but if its out of fuel, the weather is bad, etc. this little gem will still get 'em started. 4 stars instead of 5 as it would be better if it came with a small piece of metal for the stiker/shaver.
At least to me anyway. I complained that the tinder you need for a fire steel has to be small and dry and works much better with an accelerant like  char cloth or cotton with petrolium jelly. The mag bar has it's own accelerated tinder built right in after a few practice trials, you should be able to ignite the magnesium with a few strikes if you can not with just 1.Have a small pile in some collected tinder and once the pile is going it stays hot long enough for the tinder to flame up.for 8 bucks try it out at least for fun anyway.
It works well, cheap way to make a fire, not heavy and only use a very small room on your survival kitCons:The product does not come with any kind of striker/shaver attached. This tool could really benifit from a small piece of metal to use as a striker and to shave magnesium off.If you shave magnesium off and striking the flint with your knife will dull the blade pretty quickly. You can find a special striker for carring with it. Personaly I use the one that came with the  Coghlans Flint Striker.NOTICE: If you plan to fly to diferent location to start you journey be carefull you are  not allowed to carry it in your luggage or in your carry on bags
Tested this out last week and was amazed how easily it worked, if you're patient.I was simply testing the concept, not a full wilderness test, just did it outside on top of an old receipt.1.  Use the included saw (back and forth, not up and down) to generate the mag dust, dime says is MORE than enough, I used less.2.  Turn it over and scrape the fire steel with the BACK of your knife (assuming the back is squared).  When doing this, it may be helpful to hold the knife in one position and pull the start UP, this way your sparks remain in one spot for more heat and you're not accidentally disturbing your tinder by hitting with the knife.The secret is waiting until you have enough magnesium dust, and at least moderately good tinder.  Once the mag ignites, it burns hot and probably for about 60 seconds, be ready to put small stuff on it within 20 seconds.  Good luck!
This loader works very well.  I would have rated It 5 stars except for one thing: the slot that holds the baseplate of the magazine in place while loading was not quite wide enough to accommodate the baseplate of the factory 15-round magazines for my Beretta 92FS.  I could use the loader, but the magazine was crooked (due to the baseplate not fitting in the slot properly).  After taking a few minutes with a Dremel tool to widen the slot by about 1/16&#34; the loader works great. The 92FS 15 round mag has a pretty thick baseplate so if you are using this for other magazines it may work great right out of the package.  Putting aside the requirement for the modification this loader is a very good value for the price.  A real time saver (and thumb saver) for those high capacity magazines.
WOW THAS all I can say, this speedloader has saved my fingers, after having to load over 70K in ammo by hand. I.E. using my bare hands no help, the blisters were painfull, NOW this little wonderful gadget has saved my fingers and my fellow "armorers" fingers, you slide the mag into the unit, and as the instructions say, you just squeeze, insert and release and push..OMG i was able to load 5 mags each with 15rnds, in less than a min. HIGHLY RECOMMEND this..can't wait till the others arrive.
Worst Magazine Loader I Have eve used. When my department used revolvers the ZHKS speed loader was a good product and worked well. Gut when they came out with this monster it was hit and miss. The unit was very hard to operate and the shorter 9mm, .40 magazines would slip out of the grove on the unit designed to hold any size magazine in place. The unit cause fumbleitis  with over and over again especially on the short magazines. My partner has a Glock 19 and I had a Glock 27.We both bought the Uplula from Amazon and instant improvement and loading any of our magazines. It is a few dollare more that the Hks but well worth it because you can count on it to work. I have used mine wile under strett reload and it did not miss a beat. Magazine filled in no time with every round.
If you aren't familiar with speed loaders, you're in for a treat. If you have, this one works great.  I had no trouble at all with the 92F at full 16 or 17 (I forgot which), and 45 at 11 work just fine. I did try it on a 30+ for the 92F but the plastic was not strong enough for the force needed against a spring that could hold 30+, but I don't expect that to work or consider it a negative. I think I got upward of 24 or so. For what it is intended it works great!
The manufacturer says to use their ink in their printer. Of course they are going to say that, but is it for a real reason, or just so they can make more money? I don't know.I go with the real thing, and haven't had any problems. Maybe I wouldn't have any problems with refills or generic brands, but the small difference in price doesn't make the experiment worthwhile to me. I'd rather pay a little more for this genuine HP cartridge than take a chance in causing a problem with my printer.
The problem I had with this product is that the silicone grease would migrate out of the jar and start to spread all over my workbench and I hadn't even used it!I received the item in a plastic bag. When removing the jar from the bag I noticed that the grease had leaked out of the jar so I cleaned it all up and tightened the lid on the jar then set it aside.Two weeks later, I go to use the grease and there is a big silicone grease spot about 6&#34; wide underneath the unmoved jar!If I couldn't contain the product in the jar with a tightly closed lid then I would not use this SG on my equipment.I ended up throwing it away!
As silly as it sounds this is great stuff to have around the house.  Especially around my house!  I have lots of hobbies that require use of silicone grease.  Lubricating o-rings is the number one use.  O-rings are found everywhere it seams. Faucets, my Pelican cases that store my electronics, my scuba gear, air filter housings on my ATVs and motorcycles, lawn equipment, air compressor accessories, I use it everywhere!  If you're a DIYer it pays to have a little jar of this stuff on your work bench. It's not expensive and really comes in handy!!!
